We study the power allocation in multi-user scenarios with delay-limited fading channels. The general case where both the number of users and the number of channel uses are more than one is considered. We propose a low-complexity water-filling-like algorithm with closed-form expressions for the per-user water levels. We show that the proposed algorithm maximizes the average sum-rate of the system under total power constraints on the users’ transmission powers. Moreover, the proposed algorithm is shown to outperform existing algorithms in the low-to-moderate SNR regime. VI statements, initiated by A. A binary model for the UV-upturn of elliptical galaxies is presented. It consists of a static, non-rotating stellar component, resembling a 5 Gyr old single stellar population, which forms the host galaxy, and a compact object (black hole or neutron star) that accretes matter from the companion and produces a UV excess by emission from the accretion disk. Different model parameters can reproduce the UV color, the near-IR brightness, the UV spectral slope and the UV emission line strength of elliptical galaxies. The presented model, that combines simple assumptions and physically motivated parameters, can be a useful tool to interpret the UV-upturn of elliptical galaxies. In a wireless broadcast channel with multiple antennas at the transmitter and one antenna at the receiver, it is possible and beneficial to allow some of the transmitter antennas to be turned off, as long as the signal energy is spread across the antennas. This article studies the system design question of how many transmitters should be turned on, and how much transmission power should be used, to maximize the number of receivers who can recover the transmitted information at an arbitrarily low cost. We consider the case where the transmitter has perfect knowledge of the channel state information (CSI), and the case where the transmitter only has statistical CSI. In the case where perfect CSI is available at the transmitter, we determine the optimal number of active transmitters and corresponding transmission power that maximize the number of receivers who can recover the information at an arbitrarily low cost. We then characterize the scaling of the number of active transmitters and corresponding transmission power with the blocklength of the channel code, up to logarithmic factors, for the symmetric case where the channel is invariant under permutation of the antennas. When only statistical CSI is available at the transmitter, we provide sufficient conditions for low-complexity effective coding and interference management to achieve nearly-optimal performance, and we describe a specific coding and interference management scheme that achieves within a factor of 2/3rd the maximum possible number of receivers.

Cool stars play an important role in the dynamics of galaxies by delivering energy and material away from the core. However, their influence extends far beyond their host galaxy, as they can also affect the structure of the interstellar medium (ISM) and even the galactic halo via feedback effects. Here we present new optical and ALMA observations of a peculiar cool star, named HK loops, in the metal-rich circumnuclear disk of the spiral galaxy M83. This star is located near the galactic center, only few kiloparsecs from the supermassive black hole, and is possibly growing by accretion. We report a probable ejection event of gas and the resulting broad molecular and atomic hydrogen lines, the first such detection for a cool star other than the Sun. We also detect a flow of dusty plasma from this star, which is further evidence of the complex interaction between this star and its environment. We discuss the potential implications of this discovery for our understanding of cool star feedback in extreme environments, and its connection to galaxy evolution.

In this paper we consider a system of particles interacting via binary collisions and which also interact by means of a pairwise interaction potential which is degenerate in some sense. We show that the dynamics of this particle system can be approximated, in the appropriate scaling, by a coupled system of non-linear conservation laws. The approximation is in the sense of weak convergence of probability measures on appropriate function spaces. This hydrodynamic limit is then used to study the large time asymptotic behavior of the particle system. We consider the case when the interaction potential degenerate in a Kramers sense. In this case the hard-core interaction force and the inter-particle interaction force are not opposite, and they have the same scaling with the particle density. This degenerate dynamics do not satisfy the hyperbolicity condition. We show that if the initial data are regular enough and the time interval is small enough, then the particle system approach the hydrodynamic solution as time evolve. The proof is based on the theory of viscosity solutions and the compactness method.

The InterHourly-Variability (IHV) Index of Geomagnetic Activity and its Use in Deriving the Long-term Variation of Solar Wind Speed. The InterHourly-variability (IHV) index of Geomagnetic Activity is introduced and its characteristics are defined. This is then used to characterize the long-term variation of Solar Wind Speed (SW speed) that has occurred over the past 450 years. The SW speed variation is shown to comprise two component parts, a primary component (periodic wave with a period of around 11 years) and a secondary component (a clear long-term increase). The IHV index is shown to track the SW speed variation very closely, with the change in SW speed driving the change in IHV index. The SW speed variation is shown to have an overall increasing trend, at a rate of around 20 km/s/century. This has important implications for Space Weather, as the increased SW speed directly influences how much energy the Solar Wind carries.

We present a tight binding model to study the optical properties of semiconductor nanocrystals (NCs). The total electron Hamiltonian includes a uniform background electrostatic potential and a short-ranged potential arising from the confinement in the NCs that we treat within the effective-mass approximation. We numerically evaluate the optical absorption spectra and demonstrate that it accurately describes the Mie theory results in the limit of large NC size. Furthermore, we develop an analytic solution of the infinite NC size limit that can be used to efficiently evaluate the absorption spectra of small NC systems. We apply our approach to study the optical absorption in PbSe NCs and show that the observed blueshift of the absorption edge is caused by the quantum confinement and, at large wavevectors, can be well fitted by the 2D Fabry-Pérot model. We finally discuss some implications of our results for the optical studies of plasmon hybridization and screening in NCs and semiconductor interfaces.

The chemical composition of the Type II Cepheids is relevant for understanding their evolution, dynamics and pulsation. For the first time, we report the abundances of thirteen chemical elements for the BL Her and W Vir variables. The Type II Cepheids are pulsating stars in the Cepheid instability strip of the H-R diagram and they are primary distance indicators. The knowledge of the chemical compositions of these variables is of great importance for further refinement of the P-L relationship based on the physical parameters derived from their spectra. It is also very useful to study their evolution and dynamics. Our abundance analysis was based on the integral field spectroscopy (IFS) data. In total, 56 individual spectra of 14 BL Her variables and 7 W Vir variables were used for the analysis. We employed the elemental abundance analysis technique called the spectral differential imaging (SDI). We applied a very accurate and robust analytic method of SDI which we have developed recently. We achieved an uncertainty of 0.2 dex for chemical abundances determined from individual spectra.

In this paper we develop a framework for propagating scalar fields in (Anti) de Sitter spacetimes using the concept of time ordering. We introduce the concept of a scalar propagator which describes the temporal development of a scalar field, and use this to formulate the scalar field equations of motion in terms of a time ordered correlation function. We consider the de Sitter and (Anti) de Sitter spacetimes as special cases of our more general time ordered theories, where we apply this to minimally and non-minimally coupled scalar fields. We explicitly solve the scalar propagator in these theories in global coordinates, and use this to find an approximation to the full propagator. Finally, we illustrate our results by computing the two-point function of a minimally coupled scalar field in various de Sitter and (Anti) de Sitter spacetimes. We show that the two-point function is given by the Hadamard self-correlation function in de Sitter, by the Wightman two-point function in (Anti) de Sitter with vanishing boundary terms, and by the boundary Wightman two-point function in de Sitter with a cosmological horizon.

Conservation laws are the backbone of modern physics. In particular, the principle of conservation of energy is crucial for explaining most of the phenomena in our daily lives, from the movements of celestial bodies to the interactions between particles. In the last few decades, a powerful approach to deriving conservation laws from first principles has emerged, namely, the method of Lagrangian mechanics. In Lagrangian mechanics, the evolution of a physical system is described in terms of the positions and velocities of its particles, from which one can derive the corresponding differential equations, often known as the Euler-Lagrange equations. The solution to these equations is called an extremal, and their locus in phase space is called a critical point. The necessary conditions for a critical point to be an extremal are called the Euler-Lagrange equations. The corresponding statement in the relativistic domain is known as the principle of relativity. Lagrangian mechanics has been extremely successful, but it has some notable limitations. For example, many systems of interest do not have a Hamiltonian description, for reasons including the need to explicitly consider particle positions and velocities. Thus far, there is no general method to obtain Hamiltonian dynamics from a given Lagrangian. Also, the notion of a momentum (which serves to identify a phase space point) typically only arises in special cases. Even in the presence of symmetries, the Lagrangian is rarely known a priori and often must be determined by solving an equation. Finally, conservation laws should be independent of the choice of coordinate system, but in most Lagrangian mechanics formulations, this is not the case. These limitations have encouraged the development of a new variational method known as Lagrangian field theory. This approach was initially proposed by Victor Andreevich Volodin in the late 19th century; the first systematic treatment was given by Vladimir Igorovich Éleshev and Dmitrii Aleksandrovich Mikhailov in the 1960s. Lagrangian field theory is formally similar to Lagrangian mechanics, but the evolution is described in terms of “fields” (functions of space and time) rather than “particles.” Fields need not have an assigned location; the Euler-Lagrange equations describe the evolution of field gradients. As a result, field theory provides a framework for obtaining both Hamiltonian and relativistic dynamics from a given Lagrangian. Despite these successes, Lagrangian field theory has not gained the same level of popularity as Lagrangian mechanics. One likely reason is the apparent lack of intuitive appeal of this abstract, formal approach. Lagrangian mechanics is an engineering or geometric approach, focusing on the physical laws as implemented in equations of motion; Lagrangian field theory is more of a mathematical approach, focusing on the structure of the governing equations. Another likely reason is that Lagrangian field theory has been largely restricted to applications to classical mechanics and field theory. Over recent years, this restriction has been relaxed and the approach has been applied to relativistic field theories, fluid dynamics, the calculus of variations, and even to computer vision and reinforcement learning. Astronomers presented high-precision astrometry on the VLT/FORS1 at time scales of few days for the first time. Based on images obtained in five intermediate bands between 450 and 930 nm and collected over a baseline of 2-3 days, the proper motions of various objects were determined with precisions down to 12.8±4.9 km/s, corresponding to acceleration figures of up to 8.2 m/s2. While this result can be achieved for individual objects, the most exciting results were obtained for fields containing clusters of stars. In the old open cluster NGC 7142, a group of 22 probable cluster members was identified whose kinematics suggest they are most likely associated with the cluster. An acceleration of up to 5.2 m/s2 was determined for one of these stars, the most significant measurement of its kind to date. In addition, the proper motion of another open cluster, NGC 1976, was measured for the first time, revealing an acceleration of 1.2 m/s2. The results presented here demonstrate the capabilities of modern large telescopes to measure accelerations using astrometry in multiple bands over short time baselines and therefore have important implications for our understanding of the formation and evolution of stars and their environments.

KNO3 is a promising ferroelectric material that has recently been highlighted as a promising candidate for thin film technology due to its large piezoelectric coefficient, small Curie Temperature and highверactive coefficient. However, KNO3 is prone to phase separation, which obscures its ferroelectric behaviour. In this theoretical study, using first-principles density functional theory calculations, we have studied the ferroelectric phases of KNO3 and its property evolution with changes in temperature and pressure. Our results indicate that the ground state of KNO3 is ferroelectric with the polarization pointing along the c-axis. The ferroelectric switching is likely triggered by the depolarization rotation mechanism. Furthermore, our calculated elastic constants indicate that KNO3 is likely to be a soft ferroelastic with a tendency to undergo a polar state–paraelectric state transition. We hope this study can help to clarify the ferroelectric behaviour of KNO3 and bring it to the attention of thin film communities.

Interstellar ices may provide the only reservoir of organics in the Galaxy, and thus their chemical compositions and structures are crucial to our understanding of how life originated on Earth. The simplest possible organic molecule, HCOOH, was recently detected in the interstellar medium (ISM) through its infrared vibration-rotation band at 3735 cm−1. Infrared spectroscopy of this band has now been performed for a series of solid HCOOH analogues, grown in an interstellar ice analog consisting of amorphous solid water deposited on a metal surface. The results provide strong evidence that the 3735 cm−1 band arises from quantum mechanical tunneling between local energy minima on an asymmetric double-well potential energy surface. This information will be of value in understanding the origin and evolution of carbon on Earth and other planets. Ice analogues of HCOOH have been grown in an interstellar ice analog consisting of amorphous solid water deposited on a metal surface. High-resolution infrared spectroscopy has been performed on the 3735 cm−1 vibration-rotation band of the HCOOH molecule. These data provide strong evidence that the 3735 cm−1 band arises from quantum mechanical tunneling between local energy minima on an asymmetric double-well potential energy surface. These results provide crucial information about the chemistry and physics of interstellar ices, which are vital to understanding how life originated on Earth.

In this work we study the fragmentation of a charm quark into non-relativistic bound states of light quarks, namely, mesons, using an effective theory approach. In this theory the charm quark interacts with the quantum fluctuations of the Polyakov loop, which simulates the gluon field in the underlying gauge theory. We find that the fragmentation function for the transition from a charm quark to a charged pion can be well approximated by considering the Schrödinger equation for a simple potential model, where the coupling between quark and diquark is parametrized by an effective coupling constant. We calculate this constant using heavy quark effective theory and find that, within our truncation, it is independent of the light quarks inside the initial charm quark state. The parameter of the model which effectively measures the strength of the interaction, the effective coupling constant, is determined from the experimental pion spectrum. We also calculate the fragmentation function for the transition from a charm quark to a kaon. We compare with recent LHCb data and find a much larger effective coupling constant for the transition to a kaon compared to that for a charged pion. We discuss the implication of this finding for the possible explanation of the surprising enhancement of the number of produced K+ over that of K- at the LHC.

Semenov, D., Smith, B. J., Rendón, I., & Girardeau, M. (2016). Ramsey interferometry with a two-level Tonks-Girardeau gas. Physical Review Letters, 117(7), 070401. In this paper, we introduce Ramsey interferometry with a two-level Tonks-Girardeau (TGO) gas and demonstrate its application to resolving high-precision energy levels of mesoscopic systems. Ramsey interferometry, first introduced in 1963, offers the advantage of precision energy level measurement through Ramsey zone shielding and Ramsey acceleration. We propose an analogous approach using a two-level TGO gas in which a sample level of precision spectroscopy can be achieved through interaction-induced reduced qubit decoherence. In particular, we demonstrate this approach through Ramsey interferometry of a two-level TGO gas, and show that the frequency of theRamseyRamsey light shift can be resolved with sub-kHz precision. Ramsey interferometry with a TGO gas offers a precision spectroscopy approach for molecular systems, quantum many-body systems, and other systems affected by qubit decoherence.

Ideal hydrodynamics is a powerful tool for understanding the long-time dynamics of dissipationless kinetic energy dominated systems. While much has been learned using linearized theories, nonlinearities typically render the problem intractable. In this paper, we develop a family of exact solutions of the (inelastic) Boltzmann equation, that describes a freely cooling gas with divergent internal energy, for a general cooling law that interpolates between an elastic collisional cooling and an adiabatic expansion. We characterize the solution by an entropy density, from which we derive a closed system of equations for the density and velocity. We demonstrate that for a particular cooling law, the solution exhibits singularities in the form of Dirac deltas in both the density and velocity fields. We confirm these solutions using direct numerical simulations of the inelastic Boltzmann equation, and discuss physical implications and possible applications of these solutions to, e.g., stellar collapse and galaxy formation.

In this paper, we study a special case of the quantum walk in which the probabilities of the walker stepping to the left and right are both biased by a factor of alpha in one direction. The model, referred to as a self-interacting quantum walk, may be realized in various physical systems, such as electrons on a inhomogeneous lattice. We consider a general initial condition, allowing the walker to have any fractional part, and prove that the quantum walker will settle in finite time into a pure quantum state with real eigenvalue density equal to 1. We also consider the classical analogous of this walk, where at each time step, the walker may choose to step to the left or right with some probability. While the classical walk is transient in general, we prove that for sufficiently small alpha, the classical walk will always settle into a periodic configuration. We present a numerical simulation of the time-dependent behavior of both the quantum and classical self-interacting walks. As a further application of our techniques, we prove that the quantum walk converges in distribution to the classical walk. Additionally, we study two measures of mixing time: a quantum version of the quantum return localisation, and a classical version of the Klein gas correction. Finally, we present a large deviation analysis of the classical self-interacting walk and show that the walker is most likely to end up in a finite number of cells.'

Neel order in square and triangular lattice Heisenberg models was examined using the linear spin wave method. We find that in the isotropic case, the Neel order parameter has a cusp-like divergence at the ferromagnetic Heisenberg critical point in both cases. However, a subtle difference is observed in the dispersion of spin wave excitations near the ferromagnetic quantum critical point. In particular, the longitudinal spin wave velocity in the square lattice model shows a non-analyticity at the critical point, in agreement with the recent mean field result, while the corresponding result in the triangular lattice model is analytic. This behavior is discussed in the framework of the recently proposed theory of quantum renormalization group, and a comparison with experimental observations on Ca$_{2-x}$Na$_{x}$V$_2$O$_5$ is also made. In this paper we explore the possibility to learn something from the distribution of the biggest fragment in an iron-rich, zirconium rich, 304 stainless steel sample, using artificial intelligence techniques. The goal is to check if the distribution of the biggest fragment – here named “vital trace” – could be used as a fingerprint to identify the origin of the sample and if it carries information about the processes by which the sample was formed. We run a supervised machine learning algorithm with three classes, namely “iron-rich”, “zirconium rich” and “304 stainless steel”, using as features the elemental concentrations of 26 elements and as target the vital trace distribution. We found that the algorithm was able to learn the differences between the classes and to generate different predictions for the three classes, with an accuracy of more than 70% when using only 10% of the samples to train the algorithm. We also applied a similar algorithm, this time using histological images of burns as input and found that it was also able to learn the difference between “304 stainless steel” and “fire” samples, even using only 3 burns to train the algorithm. This shows that vital trace distribution could carry information about the processes occurred before the formation of the material. We believe that this work is a proof of concept that the distribution of the biggest fragment, that could be easily lost during the manufacturing of a material, could carry information that could be used to identify processes occurred before the material formation.

The large-scale structure (LSS) of the universe today exhibits a complex spatial distribution of galaxies, seemingly at random, with an amplitude of a few tens of millions of light-years at low redshifts. This "cosmic web" is a powerful cosmological tool, which, combined with other cosmological measurements, is helping to nail down the nature of dark energy. As the largest nonlinear structure in the universe, the LSS strongly depends on the combination of matter density and dark energy density. We perform a complete LSS analyses using the halo model and Liang-Mocular method in the latest cosmological simulations, including the state-of-the-art simulations (e.g.,, Auriga and Illustris) and classic simulations (e.g., Millennium and GHALO). We then use five popular parametrizations of dark energy to modify the evolution of the linear growth factor and the evolution of the rms fluctuation of the matter density field to predict the formation epochs of halos and their impacts on the shape of the galaxy power spectrum. We finally summarize the possible results in terms of projected art maps and make a summary plot. We find that the amplitude of the galaxy power spectrum is able to break the degeneracy of the five dark energy models at the 0.5% accuracy level in the future survey, i.e., the Euclid and WFIRST missions.

The VIMOS VLT Deep Survey (VVDS) is a survey conducted with the VLT Survey Telescope (VST) deepening the census of the stellar mass in galaxies, from the young to the old universe. The total sample includes 980 early type galaxies and 1069 late type galaxies between redshifts 0.2 and 5, drawn from 44 independent fields (VVDS-44) in 32,000 arcmin2 of the sky uniformly distributed over three sky releases (VVDS-007, VVDS-Europe and VVDS-Omega). The VVDS-44 observations have already been presented in the single fields (hereafter SF) papers. These data are used to investigate the assembly history of galaxies by measuring the evolution with time of the scaling relations between the stellar mass, colour and environment, between 0.2<z<2.3. These are compared with local relations and with high-redshift analogues computed from mock galaxy catalogues built from hydrodynamical simulations, to infer the role of merging and of environmental processes in shaping the evolution of galaxies. The VVDS-007, VVDS-Europe and VVDS-Omega surveys cover 32, 24 and 18 % of the sky respectively. The paper describes the survey strategy, the dataset and the measurements made, as well as the analysis methods. The paper concludes with an overview of the main results and of the progress in the early data analysis of the wider VVDS-Infinity survey, which will study the evolution of galaxies as a function of their luminosity and rest-frame colour out to z = 6.

The paper explores the effect of exchange frustration on the magnetic caloric effect (MCE) in the J1-J2 model on the square lattice. The J1-J2 model describes coupled layers of spin-1/2 moments, where ferromagnetic (FM) intra-layer and antiferromagnetic (AFM) inter-layer exchange constants are assumed. The MCE in this system was shown to result from both a latent heat and a magnetic field effect. The former arises from the modification of the magnetic order upon cooling through the Néel temperature T_N, whereas the latter results from an induced uniform magnetization in the non-magnetic background of thermally excited domain walls. The latter effect becomes particularly pronounced in the presence of strong frustration, as it allows the MCE to remain large even at very low temperatures. Using state-of-the-art large-scale cluster Monte Carlo simulations, we investigate this issue in the J1-J2 model on a square lattice, varying the coupling ratio J2/J1 from 0 to 1. We demonstrate that the presence of frustration has only a minor effect on the Néel temperature, T_N ∝ (J2/J1)−1, but it has a profound effect on the magnetic field effect. Although the induced uniform magnetization grows continuously from zero for T>T_{NL}, where T_{NL} is the Néel-like temperature defined by T_{NL} = (J2+J1)/2, it becomes systematically non-zero below a critical frustration value J2C ≈ 0.67 J1. We determine the scaling behavior of the MCE across the full range of J2/J1 and find that it is largely determined by the induced uniform magnetization, although a residual field-dependent latent heat remains and contributes to the total heat capacity across the entire ordered range. We extract the field- and temperature-dependent isothermal entropy change ∆S(T,H) and show that it diverges as the magnetic field approaches the saturation value B_{sat}, whereas its temperature derivative ∂∆S(T,H)/∂T decreases monotonically with increasing temperature. These findings are consistent with recent theories for the field-dependent behavior of ∆S in frustrated magnets, which predict ∆S(B)∝B−B_{sat} for fields close to B_{sat}. Our MC simulations also demonstrate the presence of thermally induced domain walls, which become more numerous with decreasing temperature and give rise to an exponential increase in the corresponding domain wall tension with decreasing temperature. Mass-loss events in the later evolutionary stages of stars are critical for the understanding of the final fates of stars. Radial velocity curves of typical stars with radiative outer envelopes can be accurately modeled using theories of mass-loss processes. However, the processes that drive the dramatic mass-loss events observed in some supergiants are not so well understood. Of particular interest are the events that drive the rapid mass-loss exhibited by many of the Luminous Blue Variables (LBVs) and the Quasi-periodic Modulations (QPMs) of the radio signatures of several supernova explosions. Recent results on the rapid mass-loss of LBVs have greatly increased the number of known examples and provided a framework for explaining some of the more extreme events observed. In some cases, the observed mass-loss is well described by relatively simple, magnetohydrodynamically-driven stellar winds. In other cases, the mass-loss is more consistent with radiatively-driven winds. This might indicate that multiple mass-loss mechanisms are at work in these objects, or that more complex processes, such as clumping or substantial rotation, are involved. The QPMs observed in the radio signatures of several supernova explosions also continue for many years after the explosion. These modulations are usually well described by simple harmonic functions with frequencies near 0.25, 0.6, 1.0, 2.0, and 4.5 cycles per year. The 0.6 cycle per year frequency has also been found to decrease with time as the supernova evolves. This seems to indicate that the process that produces the modulations has memory. In most models, this requires a binary companion or another form of internal resonance. A variety of observational and theoretical approaches have been used to study these dramatic mass-loss events. Recent modeling has benefited greatly from the theoretical advancements made in the areas of hydrodynamics, magnetohydrodynamics, and nuclear reaction networks. Future work will likely benefit from the continued study of individual objects and also from coordinated monitoring programs designed to detect the onset of such rapid mass-loss.

Magnetic fields are observed in a vast range of cosmic objects, from planets in our solar system to stars and galaxy clusters. These magnetic fields have different origins, either they are part of the initial conditions of the Universe (the case for the magnetic fields of planets and stars), or they are generated by a conducting fluid (galactic and cluster magnetic fields). Yet another origin of magnetic fields, common to many astrophysical systems, is related to some process that generates macroscopic turbulence. In particular, relativistic jets, that are widespread in active galactic nuclei and gamma-ray burst (AGB and GRB) outflows, are potentially very effective emitters of macroscopically-turbulent kinetic energy. In this Letter, we report AURA data, which show that one of the AGB and GRB afterglows, the magnetic field is generated by the kinetic energy of the relativistic turbulent flow.

A random walk on a countable state space is often interpreted as a Monte Carlo simulation of a Markov chain with countable state space. In this paper, we show that a random walk on an infinite-dimensional Banach space, equipped with a suitable probability measure, can be interpreted as a strong approximation of the corresponding Markov chain, yielding a convergence result in distribution. We illustrate our results with an example from financial mathematics, study the impact of the approximation error, and present several consistency results.' The analysis presented in this paper is closely related to the study of degenerate stochastic differential equations (SDEs) with vanishing coupling terms, in the case where the underlying SDE is interpreted as a weak approximation of a Markov chain. We refer to the books of Kurtz [64] and Stelzer and Zheng [113] for detailed discussions and further references on the approximation theory for Markov chains. In our analysis, we consider a more general situation of an approximation of arbitrary accuracy by stochastic differential equations, exploiting recent results on the functional central limit theorem for continuous time Markov chains.

NGC 5033 is a Sy 1.5 galaxy, located in the Fornax Cluster at a distance of 22.4 Mpc. It has a massive active galactic nucleus (AGN), which is also the power source of the observed broad optical and ultraviolet lines and strong X-ray emission. Continuum emission at centimeter wavelengths from this source has been little studied. We have carried out new cm-wavelength continuum observations with the Very Long Baseline Array that reveal a core-jet structure for the first time. The spectrum, which is fairly flat from 80 to 6 cm, is consistent with optically thin free-free emission from a thermal electron population with a temperature of approximately 0.2 keV. The derived cm-wavelength flux density is approximately 110 mJy, which corresponds to a luminosity of L ∝ 1.2 × 10 31 W. This is slightly higher than the values estimated from lower-frequency measurements, but it is within the errors of those estimates. We speculate on the possibility that the cm-wavelength spectrum is affected by free-free absorption.

We present a direct measurement of the spatial curvature of our universe combining the information from distant supernovae Ia with the local gravity environment of the Sloan Great Wall galaxy cluster. The combined data set yields a value for curvature of −0.006 ± 0.008 (1σ), corresponding to a flat universe with 96% confidence. This measurement is consistent with a curvature of 0, as expected for a universe described by general relativity with a cosmological constant. However, we also find a significant statistical correction to the measured value of the cosmological constant of ΔΛ = −0.054 ± 0.032 (1σ), corresponding to an open universe with 99.99994% confidence. This correction, which we find to be consistent with statistical fluctuations expected from measurement uncertainties, provides a robust determination of the universe's spatial curvature. The spatial curvature of our universe has significant implications for the laws of gravity. The spatial curvature is proportional to the density of matter and hence a detection of curvature rules out large-scale matter distributions required to explain the observed acceleration. We suggest that this detection, in conjunction with previous observations of an accelerating universe from supernovae and the cosmic microwave background, necessitates the introduction of novel forms of energy with negative equations of state, such as dark energy.

Neutron--proton scattering is one of the fundamental interactions in the universe. The low-energy parameters of the neutron--proton interaction describing low-energy effective interactions in the scattering domain are of crucial importance for various nuclear, particle, and astrophysical phenomena. These low-energy parameters are usually determined by a comparison of the phase shifts of the partial waves of the neutron--proton scattering derived in the effective-field-theory framework with the corresponding experimental data. In this paper, a procedure for determination of the neutron--proton scattering low-energy parameters on the basis of the modern experimental data from partial-wave analyses is proposed. The suggested procedure includes the following steps. First, a database of all available phase-shift data with a fit to all the data is generated. Second, all the data are divided into four energy regions. In each of the energy regions, the parameters of the two-parameter potential model are adjusted to the phase-shift data with an error estimation. Third, the sum of the squared residuals is calculated for each data set. Fourth, the obtained sums are fitted to the functional form, and the parameters of the function are adjusted. Fifth, the procedure is applied for the four energy regions considered. The proposed procedure was applied to phase-shift data on the basis of the most up-to-date partial-wave analyses by the GWU, CSFL, and IUF groups. The performed fits gave the following values of the neutron--proton scattering low-energy parameters: {C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, C6, C7, C8} = {0.0726, -0.0748, 0.0023, -0.0032, 0.0069, -0.00028, -0.00058, 0.00004} fm-3. The reliability of the obtained results was verified by performing a root-mean-square analysis and calculating the corresponding statistical characteristics of the fitted parameters. The obtained results for the low-energy parameters are in a good agreement with the current recommendations of the Nijmegen group and the latest calculations performed within the EFT framework. The performed analysis also demonstrated that the energy regions around the K- and P-wave phase shifts provide the most accurate determination of the corresponding low-energy parameters.

SNR G18.8+0.3 (G32.4+0.1) is a member of a small class of Galactic SNRs interacting with molecular clouds. In this letter, we report on new VLA 20 cm, ATCA 1.1 and 8.6 GHz, and EVN 5 and 8.4 GHz observations of G18.8+0.3. We also include X-ray data from a Chandra ACIS observation. In our new radio images, we find a compact structure, as previously seen at 8.6 GHz, but with a more complex and unusual morphology at 20 cm and at 1.1 GHz. In addition to a shell-like structure, we find a prominent central peak, a secondary peak to the south, and a filamentary structure to the southwest, most likely indicating shocked clouds or compressed magnetic fields. The secondary peak is visible only at 1.1 GHz, but not at 8.6 GHz or in the 8.4 GHz image. Comparing the radio and X-ray emission, we detect X-ray emission coincident with the peak of the secondary and filamentary radio peaks and to the southwest of the shell. We also see X-rays from hotter gas along the southeastern and southwestern edges of the shell. In addition, we see X-ray emission from the radio SNR itself. We discuss the implications of our results for the mechanisms responsible for the radio emission from G18.8+0.3, the evolution of the interaction between SNRs and molecular clouds, and the potential formation of population of mini-pcgs.' Post-T Tauri stars (PTTs) are semiregular late-type stars similar to T Tauri stars. However, their evolution timescale is significantly longer, of the order of several hundred million years. PTTs are proposed to have formed via the same process as TTauri stars (TTSs), but with additional mass-loss via fast stellar winds. In recent years, infrared surveys have revealed the possible existence of circumstellar disks around PTTs, although not all PTTs show signs of these disks. In this paper we report the discovery of three PTTs with unusual circumstellar dust disks. The anomalous dust disks of PTT2, PTT4, and PTT5, have inner radii of 0.26", 0.43", and 0.12" respectively, as determined from mid-infrared imaging. These radii are an order of magnitude or more smaller than those of typical dust disks around PTTs. We propose that these unusual dust disks may be caused by a planetesimal bombardment event, caused by the passage of a giant planet around the star. We investigate the detectability of such planetesimal bombardment through transmission spectral analysis, finding that PTT2 and PTT4 exhibit significant stellar metallic enhancements, while PTT5 exhibits possible stellar metallic enhancement. We discuss the possible origins of the planet, but cannot distinguish between the theories of dynamical capture, formation in situ, or migration from another system.

The Multiband Imaging Photometer for Spitzer (MIPS) is an infrared camera with capabilities similar to those of the Infrared Space Observatory but operating on the Spitzer Space Telescope. This camera was used to make observations of several stellarforming galaxies at 70 μm. Absolute calibration and characterization of the camera at 70 μm are presented. The accuracy of the 70 μm transfer function is quantified by observing a set of photometric standards, and uncertainties are found to be 5.3% at 30 μm brightness, 6.1% at 45 μm, 7.7% at 60 μm, and 9.3% at 90 μm. Stellar color and temperature estimates are compared to those derived from Infrared Array Camera data, and the two datasets are shown to be in excellent agreement given the expected errors from both instruments. Next, the 70 μm PSF is characterized, with the measurements indicating that the half-power resolution is 14.3 μm, the full-width at half-maximum is 23.2 μm, and the average background surface brightness within the PSF is 1013.2 MJ/sr^2. Absolute calibration is performed by observing Uranus at 70 μm and yields a flux of 357.8225 μJykpc2. Additionally, observations of the outer regions of five galaxies at 70 μm confirm that the 70 μm emission is clearly extended, with surface brightnesses of 23.2 μm−2 less than that of the background at the 50% level. Further analysis of these data indicates that the observed intensity is consistent with that of an exponential disk at 70 μm with scale lengths of ~4.2 kpc, smaller than but in good agreement with other wavelengths of observations.

We present here a model for the X-ray spectrum of the type 1.9 Seyfert galaxy NGC 4151. The spectrum, from 0.7 KeV to 10 kev, has been modeled as a combination of starburst and active galactic nucleus (AGN) components. In particular, the starburst component is represented by a combination of thin interstellar clouds with a range of metallicities and cloud temperatures, parameterized by a simple ionization balance. This model has been compared to the spectrum observed by the X-Ray Telescope (XRT) aboard the Swift satellite, and has been shown to provide an acceptable representation of the overall spectrum. The AGN component is represented by a power-law, absorbed by both the Galactic column and the toroidal structure around the central black hole. This model, along with a small contribution from starburst emission at low energies, can also provide an acceptable fit to the X-ray spectrum.

In this paper we present rotational widths for 102 galaxies, measured from our opticalintegral field spectroscopic sample of spiral galaxies. We combine these widths with new optical photometryfrom the Sloan Digital Sky Survey Data Release 12, improved distances from the Surface Brightness FluctuationSpite Plate Method, and a dynamical Tully-Fisher relation to produce a comprehensive model forthe full rotation width - luminosity relationship. We find that the residuals in the rotation widthsfor a particular galaxy are strongly correlated with the surface brightness of that galaxy. This result isconfirmed by an investigation into the cause of the residuals - seeing-related errors. Using a dynamicalTully-Fisher relation which is robust against seeing-related errors, we find that the residuals in theTully-Fisher relation are entirely attributable to the surface brightness of the galaxy. Therefore, we presenta method for predicting the rotational width of a galaxy from its optical luminosity, using only redshiftand surface brightness observations. We apply this relation to an external dataset of 31 galaxies with known optical luminosities androtation widths, and find that the predicted rotational widths are on average 12.2% larger thanthe observed rotational widths. While this offset is significant, it is considerably smaller than theseeing-related errors found in the above analysis. Therefore, we conclude that our new, surfacebrightness-sensitive rotational width measures are an improvement on those presented in our previous paper. Wehope that this new version will be of use to scientists working with optical rotation widths but havingsubstantial concerns about the seeing-related errors in the published Tully-Fisher relation.'

A brief abstract of a scientific paper from arXiv.org. “Cranked Hartree-Fock-Bogoliubov calculations for rotating Bose-Einstein condensates” by N. G. Berloff and P. S. Julienne (2015). This paper describes a method to solve the time-dependent Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC) equation with a rotating potential. The paper focuses on the mean-field Gross-Pitaevskii equation (with a non-rotating trap) but includes a brief discussion of how to extend the method to the time-dependent Bogoliubov-de Gennes equations. The method is tested on the case of a non-interacting, non-rotating BEC crossing the unit magnetization quantum trangle. This provides a good test of the method as the initial state is known exactly. The paper also discusses how to apply the method to realistic systems, which may include interacting bosons and/or a rotating trap.

Recent observational campaigns have discovered a widespread, but inhomogenous, CIV galactic wind from starbursting galaxies at high redshift, identified through characteristic blueshifted CIV absorption associated with the outflowing wind. We use hydrodynamical simulations to investigate the wind properties around galaxies at redshifts z = 3-5, when the typical escape velocities of z = 3-5 galaxies are of order 200 km/s. The fraction of baryons in stars of these galaxies at high-redshift is typically 80%, and thus likely progenitors of local ellipticals. We identify four primary wind signatures, which can be distinguished by detailed spectra and spatial resolved observations: a broad component from winds driven by SNe and stellar winds from aged stellar populations, a dense shell around the shocked interstellar and intergalactic medium, and gas temperature and ionization state driven winds from young massive star populations. The combined effects of these diverse wind signatures leave characteristic imprints in the CIV equivalent width and spatial profile, which can be used to distinguish galactic winds around high-redshift galaxies from other sources of CIV in the IGM.

In the standard fireball model of gamma-ray bursts (GRBs), the afterglow emission is thought to be mainly powered by the transferred shock wave ploughing through the circumburst medium (CM). In this paper, we point out that the circumstellar wind (CSW) from the GRB progenitor can also form a wind-shaped CM. The inner part of the CSW has a velocity of a few hundred km s-1, which is much higher than that of the photonuclearCompton scattering shell. As a result, the wind would sweep up the shell and form a density structure like a cocoon, while the swept-up material would cool the shock front and produce an observable X-ray afterglow. We show that this mechanism can potentially explain the extended X-ray emission observed in some afterglows. For some specific parameters of the CSW and GRB, this model can also account for the optical/IR afterglows in some GRBs, and can naturally produce the shallow decay phase in some X-ray afterglows. We conclude that the X-ray and optical/IR afterglows of some GRBs may involve a wind-shaped CM.

The min-sum decoding algorithm is widely used for forward error correction (FEC) in various coding schemes, such as the low-density parity-check (LDPC) and the convolutional code. Its decoding performance is very sensitive to the initial message passed in the algorithm. A good initialization is essential for the algorithm to converge, but the initialization schemes proposed in the literature are usually suboptimal. In this paper, we investigate the degree optimization and stability condition for the min-sum decoding algorithm. We first consider the block error probability of the min-sum algorithm for the binary-input memoryless channels. The error probability is found to be a sum of probabilities of error events in a region around the first nontrivial fixed point. We then find the region of interest in the probability expression, and show that the error exponent is a convex function of the channel normalized degrees. We then propose a method to calculate the channel normalized degrees by solving a system of equations, which can be used as the stability condition for the min-sum algorithm. Finally, we show through both numerical examples and explicit formula for general LDPC codes that the stability condition is almost always satisfied, and is tight for some codes.

We present high frequency (43.7-111.4 GHz) linear and circular polarization observations of fifteen AGNs from the BL Lac object frame, consisting of six quasars, six BL Lacertae objects, and three galaxies. Five of the sources were observed to have correlated linear and circular polarization on time scales ranging from tens of minutes to over an hour, while no linear polarization was detected on time scales longer than a few minutes. The observed polarization variability in these sources is best explained by jet rotation occurring in a helical magnetic field, rather than by spatial variation of intrinsic polarization as in orientable AGN models, or fluctuation in magnetic field strength as in stochastic magnetic field models. These results are consistent with a magnetic field structure that is dominated by a helical component. We also present nine-epoch imaging polarimetry at 22 GHz of the core of 3C84. During each epoch, the 22 GHz core became fainter, but the linear polarization remained constant at approximately 3% linearly and 1.5% circularly. This indicates that the polarization position angle remained constant within the measurement uncertainties.

We present late-time X-ray observations of the nearby Type Ibc core-collapse supernova 2018crp with the Chandra X-ray Observatory and review its observational and modeling signatures. We measure an X-ray luminosity of (4.6 ± 1.0) × 1033 erg s−1 at a Galactocentric distance of 4.4 ± 0.3 kpc, assuming the distance to the Large Magellanic Cloud is 50 kpc. We compare this luminosity with modeling predictions from three distinct progenitor models for the Type Ibc SN 2018crp: a naked helium star (a Helium star with no external hydrogen or dust layer), a stripped-envelope star (a star with a hydrogen or helium envelope, but not enough to classify it as a blue supergiant), and a compact Wolf-Rayet star. All progenitor models predict X-ray luminosities that are highly inconsistent with the observed value. We determine that the X-ray emission from the forward shock radius must be suppressed via a break in the electron energy distribution; the suppression could be due to either a significantly steeper electron energy distribution (which requires a much faster ejecta expansion velocity or larger explosion energy), or a low-density environment surrounding the shock-suppressed region. We thus present evidence against the compact Wolf-Rayet star progenitor model for Type Ibc SN 2018crp and, in general, favor more extended, lower-velocity explosion models for these transients. Type Ibc supernovae, or hypernovae, are a rare class of explosive stellar events that are generated by core-collapse of massive stars. Their classification is based on their observed spectra, with Type Ibc supernovae showing hydrogen or helium features in their spectrum, but lacking sufficient features of a broad absorption line supernova. The recent discoveries of long gamma-ray bursts (GRBs), also known as hypernovae, have opened up new possibilities to probe their origin. Observational constraints on the location of long GRBs suggest they are associated with the deaths of very massive stars, though the details of their progenitors are not fully understood. Two long GRBs ( GRB 170729A and GRB 160821B) were observed in the local group of galaxies, and in one of these (GRB 160821B) late-time X-ray observations were also obtained. Constraints on the progenitor star and explosion geometry can be obtained from the observed properties of these transients. Massive stars are formed in clusters. Their massive radiative and mechanical energies profoundly influence their environment. Despite their prevalence and crucial impact, the massive star formation process, particularly in its earliest phases, is difficult to observe due to the high spatial resolution and sensitivity needed. The water masers arise only in actively forming massive stars and gas reservoir, and so provide an excellent probe of this earliest phase. Using new Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) observations, we detect 23 new radio water masers associated with the high-mass star formation in the Nuclear Disk of the Milky Way. The distribution, velocities, and dispersion of the water masers are consistent with them tracing an inclined rotating disk. The dynamical mass of the disk is estimated to be (3.6±0.7)×10^5 M⊙, comparable to the previous upper limit of the Nuclear Disk. This, along with the coincident far-infrared and γ-ray emissions, suggests the current high-mass star formation in the Nuclear Disk is in an early stage with substantial amounts of gas and dust.

Magnetic materials that do not exhibit long-range magnetic order at low temperatures are of great scientific interest. In some of these cases, “geometrical frustration” has been shown to lead to novel behavior. Sr3NiRhO6 and Sr3NiPtO6 are isostructural frustrated, antiferromagnetically interacting magnetic systems that do not exhibit long-range magnetic order down to 20 mK. To characterize this, we have utilized magnetic neutrons scattering, which reveals a number of interesting features, including spinon Fermi surface fragmentation. We discuss the implications of our results on the nature of quantum spin liquids, as well as possible relationship to recent proposals for room-temperature superconductivity in this system. The Milky Way (MW) accreted tens of satellite galaxies over its lifetime, some of which may have survived to the present day. These satellites, which can have masses ranging from 10s to 1000s of times that of the MW, can leave a coherent signal in the form of the stellar halo. Until now, such a signal has not been detected. Here I present a set of N-body simulations that demonstrate that satellite galaxies with the right properties can leave such a signal even after being completely disrupted. These simulations, which include the full response of the host halo and satellite to their interactions, are shown to match the properties of the stellar halo observed today. The accretion of such galaxies can therefore explain the stellar halo of the MW, a constraint which was previously thought difficult to satisfy. This is possible because the disruption of satellite galaxies leaves both dark and stellar haloes in the MW, and this stellar halo can be detected in current data. This work highlights the utility of galaxy haloes in exoplanet detection efforts, as many of the nearest bright stars are surrounded by faint stellar haloes that should be detectable with current instrumentation.

We present the third and final paper in a series studying the Homunculus on the Eta Carinae star. The Homunculus is a strong, bipolar shock-generated optical nebula encircling the stellar core and formed in a major outburst about a century ago. In the first paper, we described how previous studies had shown the Homunculus to be most clearly represented as an oblate spheroid, with a major axis of 17 – 20 and a flattening of 0.33 – 0.4. In this third paper, we investigate the dynamical structure of the Homunculus by modeling it as a rotating gas torus, i.e. a donut. The Homunculus has been known to be highly asymmetric since its discovery, with a prominent hourglass-shaped front and a wide, wavering, bipolar back. These latter two features suggest that the Homunculus has a bipolar outflow along its axis of symmetry. By modeling the Homunculus as a donut and assuming that the equator rotates much faster than the poles, we have found that such a bipolar outflow can naturally produce the hourglass shape and wavering width seen in the Homunculus. In fact, our models with fast equator rotation (approximately 250 km s-1) very closely reproduce both the Homunculus shape and wavering width. We thus conclude that the Homunculus must have a fast, bipolar outflow along the rotation axis, likely resulting from the main outburst some hundred years ago.

Co-doped TiO2 films with various Co doping levels were synthesized by sol-gel process and investigated by structural, transport and magnetic measurements as a function of O2 partial pressure during deposition. The crystalline phase of the films was verified by X-ray diffraction and revealed anatase for all samples. A transport study revealed that incorporation of Co in TiO2 matrix enhances the charge transport characteristic of the films. Magnetic measurement revealed superparamagnetic behavior for samples with low doping levels and ferromagnetic ordering at higher doping levels. The results were discussed in the light of the activation energy calculation. Reducing the O2 partial pressure from high to low level during deposition leads to an increase of the activation energy which can be correlated to the change of magnetic behavior from superparamagnetic to ferromagnetic ordering. * * * * * * * * Cobalt doped TiO2 thin films with various Co doping levels were deposited by sol-gel process under various O2 partial pressures. Structural, transport and magnetic measurements as a function of O2 partial pressure revealed that the formation of Co1-xToxOy solid solution is governed by the Co concentration as well as the O2 partial pressure. As Co doping level increases, the ferromagnetic ordering is observed for the films prepared under low O2 partial pressure. An increase of O2 partial pressure leads to an increase of activation energy and the change of magnetic behavior from superparamagnetic to ferromagnetic ordering can be correlated to the change of activation energy.

Recently, we presented c2d Spitzer IRS spectra of disks around T Tauri stars (TTSs) in the embedded phase, also known as the T Tauri phase. In these papers, we modeled these data with a Dusty disk plus photosphere model, finding that typical TTSs have envelope mass fractions of a few percent at outer radii of a few tens of AU. In this paper, we extend the Dusty disk model to include nine additional gas-phase lines from atomic species and H_2. We find that these additional lines can significantly improve the quality of the fits. We also test whether two-layer models, with inner and outer disk radii, improve the quality of the fits. We find that for [Ne II], [Fe I], and H_2, the two-layer models do not significantly improve the quality of the fits. However, for the [Si II], [S I], [Fe II], and [Si III] lines, the two-layer models significantly improve the quality of the fits. We conclude that the gas in TTSs' disks likely has a significant component in the molecular form, e.g., H_2. This conclusion is consistent with models of planet formation, which predict that most dust will grow into larger bodies before collapsing into molecules. Finally, we note that the quality of the fits is similar in the embedded and disk phases, suggesting that the gas-phase composition does not evolve significantly during the embedded phase.

In this letter, we propose a novel structure of a black hole (BH) called a plasma puddle, in which plasma is accreted into the black hole and behaves as an envelope surrounding a black hole. In contrast to traditional BH envirnment such as a event horizon and an accretion disk, the plasma puddle has a surface, through which the black hole emits no news. The plasma puddle becomes a perturbative BH as the plasma density is sufficiently large, i.e., the Schwarchild radius is less than the radius of the puddle. For pulsars, the inner region of the accretion disk can be considered as the plasma puddle. The existence of the perturbative BH can explain the fast fluctuation of the emission direction of pulsars without invoking the small scale BH embedded in the pulsar. We conclude that the plasma puddle provides a new perspective for BH physics and pulsar emission mechanism.

Two colloidal glasses are prepared using polystyrene particles with different sizes. In the first sample, the particles have a size ratio of 1.1, such that they are nearly perfectly monodisperse. This sample is well-described by the bottle-brush model, a semiflexible linear polymer, below the theta temperature. In the second sample, the size ratio of the particles is 2.2, such that the degree of polydispersity is highest. This sample is best described by a cluster-catcher model, a semi-flexible branched polymer. In the first sample, the particles are attractive and well-described by the Stein model. In the second sample, the particles are repulsive and well-described by a modified Stein model that takes into account hydrodynamic interactions. The results are compared to the theoretical expectations for a Lennard-Jones system, and for a Yukawa system. The data are most consistent with a combination of a repulsive screened-Yukawa potential and an attractive Lennard-Jones potential.

Floating balls that are not satellites, but co-orbit around a star are a common sight in the night sky. These co-orbitals have been observed around both normal planets and moon-like objects. The existence of co-orbital oligarchies has only recently been confirmed by numerical simulations, with no analogous explanation in planet-disk models. This raises the question of how co-orbitals are sustained, particularly in the face of strong radial diffusion. I present an analytic model of the dynamical environment around stars, in which I identify three conditions necessary for the long-term stability of co-orbitals. First, the Laplace pressure from the central star must be large enough to overwhelm disk torques, allowing co-orbital oligarchies to form and survive over time. Second, the co-orbital region must be isolated from the co-orbital exclusion region of other stars, in order to prevent stochastic ejection. Finally, the stellar density profile must be steeply decreasing with distance from the star, so that close encounters are rare and impact angles are small, allowing the satellites to remain intact. These three conditions are met in most stars, and can account for the observed co-orbital populations.

Using an AdS/CFT inspired holographic quark model, we investigate the confinement/deconfinement phase transitions of heavy quarks in an AdS space with a varying radius and found that the QCD phase transition is a second order phase transition with a lambda-like critical exponent. We also found that the number of degrees of freedom of the dual strongly coupled conformal field theory increases rapidly near the phase transition, which is characteristic of a 2nd order phase transition. Furthermore, we study the properties of mesons in the deconfined phase and observe masses that are consistent with previous studies on heavy-light mesons. We hope this work can shed some new lights on holographic QCD.
