Recent infrared observations with the Spitzer Space Telescope have revealed the presence of warm dust around several accreting low-mass stars in the cores of star clusters. This dust, likely produced in the stellar jets, is associated with dense, optically thick disks orbiting within 0.5 au of the central stars. The disks have masses of 10−7 to 10−5 M⊕ and radii of 100 to 1000 au, similar to those of transitional disks around T Tauri stars. The Spitzer observations have found no evidence for dusty disks orbiting the brown dwarf binary 2MASS J04231426+3203266, perhaps because this system lacks a jet-driven wind or because the separation of the binary is sufficiently large to prevent disk orbital resonance. The occurrence of disks around accreting low-mass stars in star clusters but not around accreting brown dwarfs in the same star clusters suggests that disk formation is contingent on processes independent of, but not incompatible with, core accretion.

Recent experimental observation of stimulated Brillouin backscattering (SBS) in plasma-based accelerators [1–3] has created considerable interest in applying this technique to inertial confinement fusion (ICF). Current kinetic-ion simulations of SBS in ICF conditions cannot replicate these reflectivities, and previous comparisons to experiments have relied on simplified models that may not fully capture the complex plasma environment. Here, we present the first global, kinetic simulation of SBS in a high-fluence, hard-sphere, electrostatic ICF plasma. For the first time, we are able to replicate both the fast-electron-beam-driven modes and the slow, spontaneous modes observed in the experiments. Furthermore, the wavevectors and frequencies of the fast modes are in good agreement with full-kinetic simulations of a two-temperature version of the fluid equations, while the slow modes are insensitive to kinetic effects, a result that we attribute to wavevector aliasing due to the discrete electron momentum grid. Inclusion of the full kinetic electron pressure term in the ion equations of motion is also shown to improve the agreement with experiments for fast-electron-driven modes, although the effect on slow modes is less clear. These results suggest that global kinetic simulations will be necessary for future comparison with SBS experiments, and we provide the first comparison of kinetic and fluid simulations for this application.

Robustness to mutations is important for an organism’s survival. As a consequence, most proteins have evolved to be robust to point mutations. However, as mutations are typically accumulated under random mating and infinite population size, this protein robustness has not been demonstrated for large populations, an environment that predominates in the real world. Here, we demonstrate robustness to large population size by evolving proteins under directional selection for high DNA binding affinity and showing that these proteins also have high mutational robustness. By evolving DNA binding sites as well as binding proteins in parallel, we also demonstrate that high binding site mutational robustness is necessary but not sufficient for high binding protein robustness. We then use detailed models to show that high binding site mutational robustness arises due to selection to minimize the effects of mutations in binding site nucleotides on protein binding energy, and that this binding site robustness can propagate to the protein. This explains our experimental and simulation results. Our study highlights the critical role of large population size in protein robustness and may explain the high mutational robustness of proteins.

Femtosecond laser pulses pass through anatomic resolution pinholes in a thin metallic film. They form a tightly focused beam, with a transverse intensity distribution like a cusp. This structure is designed to confine spin-polarized fermions to a one-dimensional potential. They interact via a potential that tends to make them parallel, and attract or repel them based on their relative spin. We observe that the fermions remain stable in this one-dimensional potential. They oscillate about the center of the trap, but never spread out and escape. They even display what appears to be tunneling to a region of slightly lower potential. This is in marked contrast to the behavior of non-fermi gases, which rapidly decay into an impenetrable Bose-Einstein condensate. Our results may be explained by a simple, empirical model based on the s-wave scattering length, and support recent speculations that atoms may be able to simulate models of one-dimensional condensed matter systems.

We report the discovery of extreme asymmetry in the debris disk surrounding the star HD 15115. The rotation vector of the outer belt is oriented at a PA of 167° compared to 180° for the inner belt. The axis of the extreme asymmetry is tilted with respect to the axis of the planet orbit such that the midplane of the disk is aligned with the planet orbit at a PA of 25°, or 90° - 167° = 83°. This is the first detection of planet-induced warping of a debris disk and the first detection of planet-induced tilting of a circumbinary disk. The observed tilt of the midplane of the disk is 1.7°. We discuss a few plausible scenarios to explain the observations including Kozai migration of a small body toward the star, enhanced eccentric instability of large particles in the outer belt, and satellite sculpting. The paper is titled "Discovery of planet-induced warping and tilting of a debris disk" and is authored by B. C. Kelley, J. B. Reylé, C. D. Russell, S. Casassus, and J. Schneider. It was published in ApJ 870, L14 on December 4, 871, and can be accessed on arXiv.org with this DOI: 10.3847/2041-8213/aaf803

Relativistic jets are key to the observed phenomenology of active galaxies. Such jets carry away the angular momentum of the central black hole and collimated region, and therefore must transport energy and mass efficiently to offset their loss through jets. In contrast to non-relativistic winds, relativistic jets can stabilize through entrainment of external gas; however, there are also numerous examples of collimated outflows that are unstable to global modes. This Letter presents the first-principles theory of such instabilities in the relativistic hydrodynamic and magnetohydrodynamic regimes, and describes how the growth rates and saturated amplitudes of global modes depend on the background accretion and jet parameters. In particular, we find that the most unstable modes are local perpendicular modes and non-axisymmetric torsional ones, with the former growing faster and likely driving rapid variability. This Letter provides the theoretical foundations for interpreting the rich phenomenology of relativistic jets, and motivates intensive scrutiny of systems with the potential to destabilize via these processes.

We present optical imaging spectroscopy of six galaxy clusters identified in the redshift range 0.2≤z≤0.6 from the Dark Energy Survey year 1 data. The clusters were observed as part of the KiDS (Kilo-Degree Survey) cluster survey, and the data have been reduced with the dielectron pipeline. We measure the red sequence luminosity function (RSLF) and colour distribution for each cluster, and estimate the total cluster light by scaling the individual RSLF galaxy contributions using the observed red sequence width. We fit a Schechter function to the RSLF and measure the bright end slope, α. We measure a median value of α=-1.22±0.03, with a distribution that peaks at α=-1.28. These values are consistent with previous studies in this redshift range, and suggest that luminous red galaxies dominate the cluster member population out to z=0.6.

Heavy quarkonia, e.g. J/ψ, etc. due to the suppression of the strong interaction between heavy quarks, are suitable platforms for the detailed investigations of the properties of nucleons and the non-perturbative nature of the strong interaction. With the newly developed approach based on the QCD multipole expansion, in which the interactions between heavy quarks and between heavy quarks and gluons are considered via multipole expansions, the ratios of various heavy quarkonia decays can be calculated in terms of the well-known quarkonium heavy quarkonium coupling constants and the spectra of hybrids. With the calculation of the spectroscopy of hybrids, the magnetic moments and polarizabilities of hybrids can also be obtained. It is found that the calculated spectra of hybrids are in good agreement with the lattice results. Finally, by taking into account the heavy quarkonium--hybrid interactions, the decay widths of various heavy quarkonia transitions are also calculated, and the ratios agree with the experimental data well. Therefore, both the spectroscopy and strong interactions of hybrids are well determined by the new approach.

Stellar multiplicity greatly impacts the formation and evolution of planetary systems. The sheer number of possible systems, however, has made observationally determining the impacts a challenge. This work utilizes the occurrence of planets around nearby stars as a function of stellar multiplicity as well as other stellar and planetary properties to elucidate the impacts of stellar duplicity. The investigation makes use of both observations from the APPLY project and archival data from Planet Hunters, as well as a novel Bayesian approach to assign parameters to validated planets from the NASA Exoplanet Archive. The results demonstrate that stellar multiplicity has a statistically significant impact on the occurrence of planets with radii less than twice that of the Earth, with higher-order multiples showing fewer planets than single stars. Furthermore, there is also a weak correlation between stellar multiplicity and the multiplicity of planets, with singles having the highest multiplicity. Planet size has no statistically significant impact on planet occurrence, though this may be due to a smaller sample size and the adopted planet population not being sufficiently representative of the overall occurrence rates. This work demonstrates that planets in multiple star systems are less likely to be large enough to potentially support life, which could have profound implications for planet formation and the prevalence of life in the Universe.

A-type stars are defined as having spectral types A0-A9, luminosities larger than the main sequence star with the same surface temperature, and color excesses near zero. These characteristics allow A-type stars to be easily identified in observational datasets. Pulsation is one of the key characteristics of A-type stars. However, the presence of A-type stars in open clusters can make it difficult to identify pulsation, as multiple stars in the same cluster are likely to be evolved relative to their surfaces temperatures. In this study, we examined time series photometry of 122 suspected A-type stars from the BELTESS survey to search for pulsation. We used the Box Least Squares (BLS) algorithm to find periodic signals in the data. We identified fourteen stars that showed evidence of pulsation, of which three are new multiperiodic delta Scuti (DSCT) stars. We identified ten pulsating B-type stars for the first time and updated the frequencies of seven known DSCT stars. We also discuss a newly identified suspect of A-type pulsation.

Applicability of layered sine-Gordon models to layered superconductors: II. The case of magnetic coupling. We extend our analysis of coupled layered sine-Gordon models to the case of magnetic coupling. First, we note that, in general, a spatially varyingLondon magnetization interacts with the charge density wave order parameter in a layered superconductor. We demonstrate, through a simple 1D Ginzburg-Landau analysis, that the magnetic coupling between the two order parameters competes with their conventional charge density wave (CDW) coupling. Depending on material parameters, such a magnetic coupling may either destroy or stabilize the charge density wave order. We verify our analytical results by carrying out a complete numerical study of the two coupled SG models using a gradient energy regularization scheme. Our numerical results suggest that in some systems the magnetic coupling may even stabilize the charge density wave order. asquarters The applicability of coupled layered sine-Gordon models to layered superconductors is analyzed in [1]. Magnetic coupling between the charge density wave order parameter and spatially varying London magnetization is analyzed. Depending on material parameters this coupling may either destroy or stabilize charge density wave order. Results of numerical study of two coupled sine-Gordon models are presented. Verification of analytical results is done using gradient energy regularization.

Comet Hale-Bopp was a remarkable visitor to Earth in 1996. It was visible in the morning twilight for several weeks, captured the interest of the public and press, and was the subject of a large number of studies in all wavelength regions. In this paper we present the results of our study of Hale-Bopp in the mid-infrared. We observed Hale-Bopp with the NASA Infrared Telescope Facility (IRTF) and the Copernicus Space Observatory in April, May, and June 1996. In these data we see evidence of polarized light from Hale-Bopp for the first time. Our observations suggest that Hale-Bopp was composed of numerous thin, strongly elongated grains of ice which were aligned nearly perpendicular to the orbital plane of Hale-Bopp and its parent nucleus. These results may be explained if the asymmetric ejection of material from Hale-Bopp's nucleus was the source of Hale-Bopp's rotation and orbital angular momentum. We also examine Hale-Bopp's dust coma and calculate its minimum orbit intersection distance (MOID). We find that the MOID of Hale-Bopp at the time of our observations was approximately 3.2 Earth radii, a value similar to the observed coma size. We consider implications of our results for models of the formation of Hale-Bopp and its parent nucleus and for future cometary missions.

This paper investigates the networked dynamic behavior of interconnected systems. For this purpose, based on the passivity theory, a sufficient condition for stability of interconnected systems is presented in terms of a quadratic matrix inequality (QMI). Unlike the existing results, the considered system is composed of interconnected subsystems, and the subsystem input includes control input and input from other subsystems. Due to the coupling between the subsystems, the presented stability criterion can be applied to the interconnected systems with delays and component mismatches. Several examples are given to illustrate the effectiveness of the developed results. In a networked system, multiple subsystems are often interrelated. For example, in a biological network, each biological process is influenced by other biological processes. Therefore, a desirable stability criterion for a networked system should consider the effect of network connections on stability of the subsystems. The stability criteria presented in this paper allow us to consider such coupling effects.

Interactions between planetesimals leads to the formation of groups and chains. This process is known as gravitational instability. It has been observed in molecular clouds and it is thought to be important for planet formation. Planet formation by this mechanism has been studied in detail. However, it has not yet been observed in stars. This is likely due to the difficulty of detecting planetesimals in protoplanetary disks, which are much more distant. I describe a new technique that can detect these objects with the help of a recently discovered instability in disks. The instability creates clumps of material that drift toward each other, increasing in density until they become unstable and form planetesimals. This has the potential to explain the extremely high density of planetesimals in the asteroid and Kuiper belts. I present simulations of the growth of planetesimals from planetesimal clumps that demonstrate this process. This work was done in collaboration with Zhongjie Gan (University of Arizona) and Jonathan J. Fortney (Harvard University).

The cluster Blanco 1, in the direction of the Chamaeleon star-forming region at a distance of 120-150 pc, was identified by Béjar et al. (2004) as a young open cluster with an estimated age of about 10-30 million years. The masses of its low-mass members have not been directly measured. In this work we estimate the masses of the 10-3 Mjup substellar members with the combination of adaptive optics imaging in the infrared and high-precision radial velocities. We derive a lower mass function of n(m) ~ m^ - 1.5, with a median value of 0.088 Mjup, i.e., 7% of the cluster mass. This is the deepest exploration to date of the substellar regime in a young cluster. The cluster Blanco 1 contains low-mass members from 30 Mjup down to the substellar domain, with a median value of 0.088 Mjup. The lower mass function is n(m) ~ m^ - 1.5.

GRB051022 was an unusually long gamma-ray burst (γ-ray burst, GRB), lasting for at least 27sec. It was detected by the Burst and Transient Source Experiment on board the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope on October 22, 2005, at 04:56:48.6 UT, at a nominal distance of 220 million light-years from Earth. While GRB durations fall into several distinct categories, this long-duration, or long burst, exceeds most widely accepted classification definitions by several orders of magnitude. In particular, it is more than 10 times as long as the second longest GRB, and many times longer than any other observed short/medium GRB. This extremely long duration could not be readily explained by standard models of gamma-ray bursts (GRBs), which associate these events with the core collapse of massive stars or the coalescence of compact objects. However, current GRB models cannot fully explain the very long, as well as shorter, bursts. Alternatively, the long duration of this event could be explained by a highly beamed emission, with the consequent high chance of being observed by a space-based observer at large distance. In this case, the burst would have produced significantly lower levels of prompt high-energy emission, as observed. However, the early-time optical and X-ray afterglows that would be expected in this case are not observed. GRB051022 emitted more than 10 times more energy than the typical long burst. The most likely explanation for this extreme luminosity is beaming: the gamma-rays were beamed into our direction from a highly misaligned beam. We can place limits on the beam-opening angle of the gamma-ray beam using these limits on the optical and X-ray afterglow. Fermi's observations of GRB051022 provided the first broadband spectrum of a gamma-ray burst, from more than 10% of the total gamma-ray energy detected by the Burst Alert Telescope all the way down to the Stefan–Boltzmann limit of infrared observation with the GEMS. The detection of optical and infrared emission in this case, despite the gamma-rays being beamed away from the observer, implies that the energy emitted in gamma-rays was less than 1% of the total. Thus the highest energy observed gamma-rays were not as narrowly beamed as previously thought, allowing for a wider range of possible sources. The prompt emission of GRB051022 lasted 27 seconds, which is the longest of any gamma-ray burst ever recorded. This event was notable not only for its extreme duration, but also for its proximity to Earth. It was the nearest GRB ever recorded, and the faintest optical and X-ray afterglow ever recorded. Massive galaxies at 2<z<2.5 are observed to have distinct MZR with elevated stellar mass and bulge mass surface densities (Sérsic index n > 4.5). We present the results of a uniform multiwavelength analysis of 14 such galaxies and find that this elevated mass structure is accompanied by elevated star formation rates (SFR>100M⊙yr-1), low concentrations (Congo et al. 2013), and high sSFR (Gargiulo et al. 2015). With high significance, elevated dynamical mass estimates and lensing signals imply massive black holes (MBH) in excess of 10^{9} M⊙, with the majority (11/14) having MBH ~10^{8.7}-10^{9.3} M⊙. Five of these massive galaxies have Spitzer/SWIRE MIPS 24μm detections, all are detected in the hard X-ray band with (0.5-2)keV luminosities ~10^{43}-10^{44} erg s−1, and eleven are Compton-thick in the hard X-ray. These observations strongly imply that the majority of these massive, rapidly growing galaxies have central massive black holes with masses at or above the regime of "monster" black holes. We combine our dynamical estimates with archival VLT and ALMA data to study the cold gas and far-infrared fine structure line energetics. Most (9/11) of these systems have signifcantly elevated CO SLEDs and high estimated He 2-10 radiated powers, with estimated starburst masses MSB ~10^{10.6}-10^{11.2} M⊙. There are three broad approaches to growing such massive bulges and central black holes in the peak epoch of star formation. In the "top-down" or mergersill scenario, the majority of these massive galaxies are the product of mergers over several hundred million years. The second is "in-place" or "normal" growth whereby these systems are growing through concurrent, normal, secular processes like gas accretion and star formation. The third is that these galaxies are growing entirely through gas accretion. Using rough constraints on the cold gas fueling rate and Eddington limit at the heart of the "maintenance mode" accretion growth, we show that these monster growth events likely require significant growth fueled by gas accretion. We combine this with Bayesian growth tracks for matching black hole and bulge masses, and find that over half (7/14) of these galaxies have double-mass milestones at z~2.3-2.6, concurrent with both the epoch of peak star formation and 24μm Spitzer/SWIRE detection. A study of the incidence of C IV absorbers along the sightlines to z ≥ 0.47 gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) indicates a high degree of clustering of C IV systems near the line of sight. Six of eleven gamma-ray bursts have more than one C IV system within 60,000 km s-1 of the line of sight. The nearest two C IV systems are separated by 45,000 km s-1 on average and no more than 5,000 km s-1 without multiple C IV systems within 60,000 km s-1 of the line of sight. The most likely explanation for the high incidence of C IV absorption along these lines of sight is that a population of dark collapsed structures is passing through our line of sight. We estimate the total matter in these structures is on the order of 1022 -1023 solar masses. The dimensions of these structures are approximately 10-4 to 10-5 parsecs, which is approximately one ten-thousandth to one one-thousandth the distance between the Earth and the Sun. The clustering and relative proximity of the C IV systems indicates that these dark collapsed structures likely have typical distances of 10 parsecs from the sites of gamma-ray bursts. Furthermore, the inferred dimensions of these structures are consistent with the size distribution of black holes that may form from the collapse of massive primordial structures such as carbon clusters, large moons, or galaxies. If confirmed, this discovery has profound implications for modeling the demographics of black holes, their interactions with their environments, and the reprocessing of electromagnetic radiation in their broad-line regions.

In this work, the effects of turbulent diffusion on the chemistry of diffuse molecular clouds are examined. In particular, the effects of weak turbulent diffusion on the radiative transfer and chemical enrichment of carbon and silicon are considered. Turbulent diffusion acts to spread material over larger spatial scales and, in the case of carbon, enhance its overall rate of depletion relative to the case without diffusion. Thus, while the total amount of carbon remains unchanged, turbulent diffusion increases the temporal contrast of carbon abundances within a cloud, thus accelerating its chemical evolution. Carbon depletion by catalyzed reactions is also accelerated due to the increasing spatial contrast of carbon abundances. Silicon is substantially less impacted by turbulent diffusion. Both the neutral and ion silicon abundances increase with time, but the increase is less than that of carbon. Overall, the presence of weak turbulent diffusion may have an appreciable impact on the chemical enrichment of carbon and silicon within a diffuse molecular cloud.

In this paper the longitudinal impedance of an XFEL undulator is calculated for operation in current-enhanced SASE (Self-Amplified Spontaneous Emission) schemes. The undulator radiation impedance is derived from the wake fields and is used to study the reflections from the input ZLWstairs filter for several current-enhanced SASE setups. The performance of the setup based on seven cells of [1] is discussed in detail. It is shown that more than 90% of the input power can be reflected with only 10% loss, which is considered very good for a proof-of-principle study. A differentially rotating force-free magnetosphere of an aligned rotator is studied. We derive an analytical solution in split-monopole approximation, which can be used for construction idealized models of the magnetosphere. The solution depends on two parameters, which can be chosen to approximate the geometry of the magnetosphere and the flux functions in the polar regions. We demonstrate how the solution can be used for construction models of the magnetosphere with different properties. In particular, the surface magnetic field is chosen so that the solutions can produce magnetars and gamma-ray burst jets. Magnetic fields and plasma in magnetospheres of rotating neutron stars are usually considered to be force-free. However, force-free magnetospheres were found only in special cases, for example when the neutron star has a very strong magnetic field or when the star is not rotating. In contrast, general rotating magnetospheres are described by the induction equation, which allows for electric currents and moving charges. The force-free and induction magnetic field models describe the same magnetic fields in different regimes and can be connected by their perturbative departures. We study analytically a general differentially rotating force-free magnetosphere with general equations of state and current distribution. We solve these general equations in the split-monopole approximation. This solution can be used for construction idealized models of the magnetosphere. The solution depends on two parameters, which can be chosen to approximate the geometry of the magnetosphere and the flux functions in the polar regions. We demonstrate how the solution can be used for construction models of the magnetosphere with different properties. In particular, the surface magnetic field can have different geometries (poloidal and toroidal) and can be time dependent. Such magnetospheres can produce magnetars with huge magnetic fields (about 10^14-10^15 G) and gamma-ray burst jets with observed fast rotating electrons.

In this paper we introduce a method for constructing Einstein manifolds of any desired signature (2m+1,1), admitting a space of twistor lines of any prescribed flag type. These twistor spaces are constructed as moduli spaces of holomorphic curves with given asymptotics, in some simply-connected Riemann surface with complex structure deformed by a holomorphic differential. This deformation complexifies the structure group of the tangent bundle, reducing it from the special orthogonal group SO(2m+1,1) to the isometry group of the corresponding Einstein metric. The moduli spaces of holomorphic curves considered here are related to the generalized Krichever construction of Einstein metrics. We classify all the obtained Einstein structures when the Riemann surface is the complex plane or the sphere. As an application, we present explicit Einstein metrics on some of the orbifolds of the standard sphere S^{2m+1}/Ω, where Ω is a fixed point free symmetry of the underlying Fefferman-Graham ansatz for the anti-de Sitter metric.

The very existence of luminous quasars (QSOs) at high redshift is difficult to explain within the paradigm of pure cold dark matter cosmology. As the most massive dark matter halos at high redshift, QSOs are good laboratories to test evolutionary models of the universe, as well as the supermassive black hole - host galaxy co-evolution. Using a sample of 12 luminous high-redshift QSOs with X-shave archived, we investigate the host galaxy dust covering factor (defined as the ratio of solid angle covered by dust to the total solid angle), and the silicate strength and colour of the mid-infrared emission, which are potential probes of the star formation rate (SFR). We find that compared to local luminous and ultra-luminous infrared galaxies (LIRGs and ULIRGs), high-redshift luminous QSOs have a significantly higher covering factor of dust, lower silicate strength, and redder infrared colour. The high covering factors suggest that these QSOs have significant on-going or recent star formation. The trends are consistent with that expected from an evolving dust-to-stars ratio, with a dust covering factor of 0.4-0.6 at z = 2.2-3.4 (where z is the cosmological redshift). There is no strong evidence for a higher proportion of IR-luminous, or active galaxies in the QSOs than typical for the bright sub-population at these redshifts, in agreement with previous studies. The observed dust and silicate properties are, however, more similar to those of local sub-millimetre galaxies (SMGs) than normal ULIRGs, suggesting the QSOs may evolve into SMGs at lower redshift. We discuss several scenarios to explain our results, including QSO-driven winds clearing out interstellar medium (ISM) and/or molecular clouds. However, we note that without measurement of the velocities and densities of the obscuring material, and the strength and shape of the quasar continuum, it is difficult to distinguish between these scenarios and to test the influence of the QSO on the host galaxies evolution.

We present the first three-dimensional X-ray cluster correlation function based on a flux-limited sample of X-ray selected galaxy clusters from the ROSAT North Ecliptic Pole (NEP) survey. The cluster sample is drawn from the compilation of Gregor et al. (2007) and covers a volume-limited, flux range of 2-5×10^-15 W m−2 in the 0.5-2.0 keV band. The resulting 3D cluster correlation function, measured in the plane of the sky, shows no indication of the usually observed decrement towards small separation, for separations up to 20 arcmin. The 3D clustering amplitude is determined to be A = 0.436 ∓ 0.058 = 0.3064 ∓ 0.0852, where the 95 % error interval is determined from 22 bootstrap resamples. This is in excellent agreement with previous results from 2D analyses of this cluster sample. The corresponding projected correlation length is r0 = 8.25 ∓ 0.61 h Mpc, where the 95 % confidence interval is determined from 20 bootstrap resamples. This is larger than the expected strength of the correlation function for a random distribution, suggesting that the X-ray selected galaxy clusters are biased with respect to the underlying mass distribution. The 3D redshift-space cluster correlation function, r(s), is determined up to separations of 40 arcmin, yielding z0 = 0.547 ∓ 0.046, where the 95 % error interval is determined from 22 bootstrap resamples.

The thermal Casimir force is attracting much attention as a medium-range interaction in nanotechnology. Recently, an analytic approach to the thermal Casimir force between metal and dielectric was proposed. The method is based on the use of the so-called dielectric permittivity spectral functions, which are measurable in the time domain. A plasma model was used for modeling the dispersive metal. It was shown that the thermal Casimir force is given by the derivative of the free energy with respect to the distance between the surfaces. The general expression for the thermal Casimir free energy was obtained. This expression was used for calculating the thermal Casimir force for various combinations of metal and dielectric parameters. It was demonstrated that the thermal Casimir force is strongly modified by dispersion of the metal. The most notable example is a change in the sign of the thermal Casimir force for a metal and a dielectric at certain combination of the parameters of these two objects

Tidal dwarf galaxies (TDGs) are often formed from material torn from other galaxies in high-velocity interactions. TDGs provide a powerful test of gravity in the high-dispersion regime, as they form at high velocity where gravity is weak. MOND does not provide such a strong test, and the disagreement with observations may suggest that MOND does not describe gravitational force in the low-acceleration regime. Consequently, modification of MOND is an interesting possibility that could resolve the disagreement between MOND and observations of tidal TDGs. We present N-body simulations showing that modifications to MOND that introduce a mass dependent acceleration scale, g0(r) ~ r-a0, where a0 is a constant, can successfully describe the dynamics of TDGs. The corresponding interpolating function, fs(R) = (a0/r)2, provides a good fit to the rotation curves of dark matter halos, suggesting it may also arise naturally from modification of MOND. We apply this interpolating function to TDGs and show that it reproduces the correct scaling of the internal dynamics of TDGs with galaxy mass, rotational velocity, and orbit orientation, without a dependence on a0. These results suggest that the observed discrepancy between MOND and tidal TDG dynamics may be explained by modifications to MOND that interpolate between thestrong and weak gravity regimes.

We present an atlas of circumnuclear regions of 75 nearby Seyfert galaxies observed with the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) aboard the Hubble Space Telescope (HST). These galaxies, which span a range in Hubble type, are among the most extensively observed Seyferts with HST. Using an unified model of active galactic nucleus (AGN) structure in which the central engine is surrounded by an accretion disk, Broad Line Region, and torus, we investigate the properties of the circumnuclear regions in these galaxies. We find evidence for spatially resolved warm absorption in the near-UV in 57% of the sample. The warm absorbers are characterized by a multi-phase structure with Doppler parameters ranging from ∼30 to ∼250 km s-1, turbulent velocities from ~10 to ~250 km s-1, and covering factors from a few percent to nearly 100%. The amount of soft X-ray flux absorbed by the warm absorber is strongly correlated with the amount of high-ionization [O VI] absorption, suggesting that the same gas is responsible for both absorptions. The multi-phase nature of the absorbing gas implies that it is composed of numerous clouds with small, non-uniform covering factors. We estimate the total column densities of individual species from the model fits and find that O VI, N V, and C IV are often the dominant ions, while gas-phase oxygen may be depleted with respect to solar abundances. We also find evidence for dust in the form of narrow absorption lines in 56% of the sample. We compare our results to recent models of dusty AGN winds, finding that the observed properties of the warm absorbers can be reproduced using obscuring columns of a few times 1022 cm-2 and velocities of a few thousand km s-1. Our sample provides the best currently available view of the circumnuclear regions of AGN and the first such atlas of its kind in the near-UV. This atlas demonstrates the feasibility of using the HST ACS to study circumnuclear regions of Seyfert galaxies in the near-UV. We find that the properties of the absorbing gas phase are generally consistent with the models of dusty AGN winds.

The Casimir force is a long-range force arising from fluctuations in the quantum electromagnetic field that is caused by the boundary conditions. The Casimir force is important in microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) and has been applied in nanotechnology to manipulate and stabilize nanomechanical systems. The origin of the Casimir force is the excitation of electromagnetic modes between the closely spaced boundaries. Therefore, changing the boundary conditions by the varying optical properties would change the Casimir force. In this work, the experimental approaches are demonstrated to change the Casimir force through the varying optical properties. Experimentally, the force is measured by using an atomic force microscope setup with a sphere and a plate as sample bodies. The sphere is composed of two layers of different materials and the plate is covered with distributed Bragg reflectors with different grating periods. The experimental data are compared with theoretical predictions and good agreements are obtained. Therefore, the experimental approaches presented in this work are feasible for varying the Casimir force by the varying optical properties and could be useful in the Casimir and many other applications.

A plasma is a very dilute collection of charged particles. The individual particles have no charge or only a very small charge, but due to Coulomb's law they can exert a force on each other. When a plasma moves with respect to a neutral, non-conducting background, the particles will experience a force in the direction of motion, called drifts. In this paper, we consider a scenario where a positively charged particle is moving towards a stationary plasma sheet. It will approach the plasma sheet and experience a negatively charged field. This field will cause the particle to move in the direction of the positive field. Before the particle can reach the plasma sheet, it will encounter a region of null field, the so-called plasmabal, in which the particle experience no force. In this region, the particles will bounce back and forth, and the motion is unstable. The particle will execute an oscillatory motion, called bounceCTL.

The supergravity (SUGRA) models, in which the soft supersymmetry (SUSY) breaking parameters are expressed as functions of only a few universal parameters, have been very popular since the early days of supersymmetry (SUSY). These models predict a specific correlation between some of the SUSY parameters, namely the masses of the Higgs bosons and superpartners, which could be tested at the Tevatron and the LHC. We point out that the current data on the masses of the superpartners, namely the lightest neutralino and the gravitino, can be accommodated in the minimal supergravity model (mSUGRA) with non-zero trilinear SUSY breaking couplings (A terms). Depending on the value of the A terms, LHC may or may not see signals associated with these interactions. In the region where LHC sees signals, the signatures are very similar to the signals expected at the Tevatron, which has currently the best sensitivity for these signals. We emphasize that this correlation is a consequence of the SUSY models and would not hold in the standard model (SM) with arbitrary SUSY breaking terms.

A compelling aspect of theories with gravity is their ability to give a complete description of the universe, from the largest-scales to the smallest. String Theory, for example, or M-Theory, are compelling frameworks for such a description, unifying all the interactions of particle physics into a single, complete, elegant theory. One such aspect, not yet fully realized, is the unification of the fundamental forces: the Strong and Weak nuclear forces, and the electromagnetic force. Supersymmetry, realized a quarter century prior to the unification of these forces, predicts that for every symmetry that preserves one force, there is another force, requiring a symmetry-conjugate, but slightly different, force. The manifestation of this in the real world is the hierarchical structure of the force-couplings: the Strong and Weak nuclear forces are tied together, and the Electromagnetic force is tied to the Weak force via the photon, which is itself an interaction of the electromagnetic force. The realization of unifying the three forces is a primary aspiration of high-energy physics, one that has yet to be realized. The challenge of realizing this, however, is one of engineering, for no current theory realizes this unification. While String Theory - which at its core is a quantum-mechanical theory of extended objects in a 10-dimensional manifold - offers a framework in which to realize this unification, it is a highly abstract framework, with no realization in terms of local quantum field theories. While the challenges of realizing this dream of physics have driven theoretical endeavour for nearly 70 years, a realization in terms of a local quantum field theory is yet to come. The latest, and most promising, framework for realizing this dream is that of M-Theory, unifying all of the physical interactions via the existence of 11-dimensional membranes. Unfortunately, these membranes, while realizing the dream of unification, also run into the same roadblock - no realization of M-Theory in terms of local quantum field theories. A boundary element method (BEM) solution of the two-dimensional Laplace’s equation in the half-plane using triangular elements is presented. Boundary conditions are applied on a part of the boundary of the half-plane. The BEM linear system is singular, which is typical for BEMs, because a Green’s function is used for representing the solution at the interior points of the domain. The BEM matrix is non-symmetric, and the use of a proper preconditioning method is required for achieving a good numerical accuracy. We propose a new technique for building the preconditioner which requires the solution of a local Helmholtz problem with a non-symmetric operator in the variational formula. We show that the proposed method provides a high accuracy solution, and that the numerical error is nearly exact, in the sense that the difference between the exact solution and the numerical solution is limited to the discretization error. The method works well even for very fine meshes with thousands of triangles. The efficiency of the method is demonstrated by several numerical examples.

A robust developmental program is essential for multicellular organisms to carry out their functions, such as formation of body plans and limbs, and to adapt to environmental change. Here we develop a theoretical and experimental framework to investigate multicellular developmental robustness, based on an epigenetic model for gene regulation. The model encompasses, for the first time, the role of cell division in developmental robustness, and our theory and experiments reveal that developmental robustness can arise from a compromise between developmental tempo and program, and between robustness to variability in cell type composition. Using this framework, we identify non-mutually exclusive avenues to improve developmental robustness. For example, increases in developmental tempo can enhance robustness; and alternative strategies to increase robustness may be to (i) reduce the influence of noise in gene expression, or (ii) reduce heterogeneity in cell composition. These results establish a theoretical foundation for multicellular developmental robustness, and we propose that our theory should enable further identification and implementation of strategies to improve robustness in synthetic systems and in regenerative medicine.

Stellar-mass black holes (BHs) are ubiquitous in globular clusters (GCs), yet their influence on the dynamics of cluster stars is not well constrained. Here we show that the presence of an intermediate-mass BH in a GC modifies the equilibrium structure of the cluster, with an overall expansion of the stellar distribution. In contrast with earlier studies, we show that the presence of a black hole hardly alters the structural properties of young GCs, and is only significant for older clusters. We perform N-body simulations with varied particle numbers and show that our findings are consistent with the presence of a central intermediate-mass black hole, of a mass above ~20% of the total cluster mass, having been formed via runaway mergers of individual stars and stellar remnants. This implies that BHs of high masses could have formed in GCs via processes occurring at low efficiencies during their early dynamical evolution. This provides a novel means for the formation of massive stellar-mass BHs, and may help to resolve an apparent contradiction between observations of stellar-mass BHs and the predictions of standard GC evolution.

This paper investigates the second-order optimality of electrical impedance tomography (EIT). For the standard elliptic EIT inverse problem, a state that has minimal energy relative to the specified electrical boundary conditions does not necessarily have a corresponding physical shape. This phenomenon is often referred to as impedance artifacts. It has been shown that this problem can be cast as a constrained second-order minimization, subject to the incompressibility constraint and a globalization condition. In this work, we present a unified first- and second-order approach to shape optimization for EIT. We show that the associated energy functional is of second order in the deviation of the current state from an optimizer. We apply a convex relaxation to the second-order shape derivative in order to characterize the second-order shape derivative by means of the Dirichlet energy, and thereby reduce the analysis to the level of convex analysis. Numerical experiments are presented to illustrate the theory.

Strain localization in a shear transformation zone (STZ) model for amorphous solids is examined. In this model, the amorphous solid is composed of particles interacting via a short-range, repulsive core and a long-range, attractive tail in a potential that is sheared, below the glass transition temperature, Tg, to generate an amorphous solid. In quasistatic deformation, regions of high shear stress,τ(shear), form from localized regions of high strain, e(loc), which propagate as wave fronts described by a strain localization theory. Specifically, a transition from spatially extended to localized strain is observed as the ratio of the localization length, λ, to the initial system length, L0, increases. An analytical theory describing the spatial, temporal, and frequency dependent shear modulus, G(τ,ω), and its relation to the shear stress and strain waveforms is developed, which allows for analysis of the frequency dependence of localized shear stress and strain, τ(loc)(ω) and e(loc)(ω). τ(loc) is observed to have three distinct regions with decay characteristic of critical exponents in scale-free space, increasing with frequency as 1/τ(loc)∼ω^{νz}, where ν=0.5 is the divergence of the correlation length, and α and β, which depend on details of the decay of the potential, describe the frequency dependence of the critical strain amplitude required to induce strain localization. e(loc) exhibits similar critical exponents to τ(loc) except with different critical amplitude exponents α=νz=1/2 and β=1/2. Furthermore, the critical exponents and scaling laws are compared to those of supercooled liquids (in which this model was originally proposed to explain) and those of amorphous solids with a different potential, demonstrating consistency between the predictions of the STZ model and these observations. These results show that the strain localization theory for amorphous solids, derived from a theory for supercooled liquids, can provide a framework for understanding the mechanical response of amorphous solids across various different model systems.

A long-standing controversy in X-ray astronomy is whether high energy (HE; 100-300 keV) X-rays are generated by the magnetic threads that connect the neutron stars (NSs) in neutron star binaries or by an accretion disk around a black hole (BH). Recently, absorption-like features at ~60-300 keV in a few magnetar candidates, including Mkr 841, were reported and attributed to either a cut-off power-law (CPL) or cyclotron resonance scattering feature (CRSFs), depending on the spectral analysis method used. The feature at 100-300 keV in Mkr 841 can be modeled equally well by a CPL or a CRSF. However, both the CPL and CRSF models are acceptable with large reduced χ2 values, 1.8 and 3.2 for the CPL and CRSF models, respectively. To better understand the spectral complexity of Mkr 841, we reanalyze the publicly available NuSTAR and *-Newton data using different methods. We confirm the CPL model with an exponential cut-off at ~120-180 keV, but not the CRSF model, in Mkr 841. The sharp cut-off at ~120-180 keV is well represented by a pure absorption model. Furthermore, we detect a broad band X-ray continuum extending to at least 50 keV. The phenomenological model consisting of an attenuated CPL and an absorption model successfully accounts for the broad band X-ray continuum, which likely originates from electron scattering in the magnetosphere or in the vicinity of the NS. The broad band X-ray spectrum can also be interpreted as a NS wind. These findings indicate that the magnetar scenario is a more reasonable interpretation for Mkr 841 than a black hole scenario. Mkr 841 is known as a highly magnetized neutron star with the surface magnetic field of approximately 4.8∼8.3 × 10^{13} G, the highest magnetar surface magnetic field known. It has a spin period of 2.0378 s and a fast-down jump of the period between 2010 and 2016, which is among the fastest observed in magnetars. Several absorption-like features have been reported in Mkr 841 at ~60-300 keV, including a absorption line at ~93.3 keV reported by INTEGRAL in 2004, an absorption edge at ~130 keV reported by Swift in 2010, and an absorption feature at ~60-300 keV reported by NuSTAR and *-Newton. A chain-boson model is proposed to explain the decoherence and relaxation of a few coupled SQUIDs in a phonon bath. The model contains a set of oscillators coupled to the low-lying modes of the environments, which are modeled by an harmonic chain. It is found that the phonon bath induced decoherence and relaxation can be effectively described by a pure decay process, whose rate is determined by the spectral density of the bath and the dimensionless coupling constants between the central system and the bath. In particular, when the dimensionless coupling constants are small, the dynamics of the system can be approximately described by a Lindblad equation, from which the energy relaxation and decoherence of the coupled SQUIDs can be understood. The theory can be applied to study the decoherence and relaxation in other hybrid systems consisting of a few coupled quantum systems and harmonic chains. This model can also be used to study the quantum effects of a coupled SQUID system immersed in a bosonic bath. The quantum dynamics of the coupled SQUID system can be solved by numerically diagonalizing the corresponding Hamiltonian in a truncated Fock space. As an example, we study a phase qubit (the coupled SQUID system) in a linearly coupled chain, which is capable of simulating two-dimensional correlated dynamics. Numerical simulation results show that, when the chain length is even and the applied magnetic flux in the qubit loop is close to a half-flux quantum, two-dimensional quantum chaos takes place. The quantum entanglement between the two coupled SQUIDs increases with the number of qubits in the bath, and displays a behavior of wave nature with the increase of bath dimensionality.

I present a new analysis of the proper motions and radial velocities of F and G dwarfs in the solar neighborhood. This sample, obtained from the Spectroscopic Properties of Nearby F and G Dwarfs (SPONGES) survey, is restricted to stars with 7.5 kpc < rho < 22.5 kpc and |z| < 1 kpc and a color, (G* - r* - r), that places them between 1.5 and 3.5 mag below the main sequence. By statistically comparing the heliocentric radial velocities to their respective absolute visual magnitudes, I infer the full 3D kinematics of this sample. In agreement with previous analyses, I find that the tangential velocity, Vt, increases with median Galactocentric radius, Rv. I additionally find that Vt and Rv are correlated at a significance of 4.2σ, meaning the velocity field of F and G dwarfs cannot be explained by a simple Galactocentric radial dependence. I attribute this velocity covariance to the complex evolution of the Milky Way, which likely included a early fast migration period and subsequent accretion of satellite galaxies. I also analyze the individual proper motions and do not find evidence of a kinematically anomalous population. This work shows that a broad sample of local F and G dwarfs can be used to study the 3D kinematics of the Milky Way as a function of age and provides valuable constraints for simulations of the Milky Way’s formation and evolution.

In this paper we study random antiferromagnetic Heisenberg spin chains in a transverse field using the iDMRG algorithm. We calculate the correlation function amplitude and the entanglement entropy using CFT techniques, and compare the results with iDMRG numerical simulations. We find that the CFT predictions match the numerical results very well for system sizes accessible with iDMRG. Moreover, we argue that the numerical results are consistent with a conformal field theory description of the vicinity of the large spin limit, where the spin chain can be thought as a large number of decoupled one-dimensional segments. In particular, our CFT analysis allows us to compute the conformal blocks decomposition of the correlation function amplitude, that in turn permits to explicitly calculate the entanglement entropy. We find that the leading term in the entanglement entropy is linear in the subsystem size, in contrast to the logarithmic law expected from conformal field theory in one dimension. Finally, we perform a finite size scaling of the entanglement entropy, finding that the leading coefficient is independent on the subsystem size, in agreement with the CFT prediction.

Recent optical and near-infrared images have revealed a thin, comet-like structure around several young stars, dubbed comet-like tails. Observations of the 126my-old V4046 Sgr showed a double-tailed morphology with a separation of ˜0.5″, similar to that of comets. Subsequent studies have revealed that this is a rather common phenomena in young stars, found in roughly 30% of the investigated young stars. Several hypotheses have been proposed to explain the observations, including close encounters with terrestrial planet-mass objects, loss of kinetic energy from the cometary-like extension, or jet-related feedback from the central star. However, direct observational evidence is still sparse. Here, we report on the ALMA observations of a transitional disk around the young star HD163296, with corresponding HST observations at optical wavelengths. We have identified distinct Na I absorption lines corresponding to the star, the disk and the halo of the transitional disk around HD163296. The observed spatial distribution and velocity structure of the Na I lines are well matched with the predictions of hydrodynamical simulations of the interaction between the stellar ejecta and the disk. The observed absorption lines are consistent with the ejecta having a cometary morphology with a highly significant forward-facing tail. This is the first observational evidence for the interaction of supernoave ejecta with a protoplanetary disk.

Active regions (ARs) are areas of the Sun where new solar activity, such as sunspots and flares, is likely to appear. It is important to understand the characteristics of these regions since they can have a substantial impact on the Earth's weather and environment. Traditionally, solar telescopes have focused on sunspots, seeing them as dark spots on a bright surface, but recent studies have shown that plage, the area around active regions in the Sun's surface, has a much higher contrast than sunspots. Fourier analysis is a common technique in the fields of signal processing and finance, where it is used to study the frequencies present in a signal. In this paper, we apply a form of Fourier analysis to plage regions on the Sun and identify frequencies present. These frequencies correspond to regions in the frequency-wavenumber plane where absorption and scattering events in the Sun's atmosphere occur. These atmospheric events are tied to the processes occurring in active regions and can be used to study their characteristics.

Graph codes are a powerful family of error-correcting codes that find many applications in storage, transmission, and computation. For high performance, usually high rate codes are desired. But for high rate codes, maximum a-posteriori (MAP) decoding (optimized for maximum likelihood (ML) decoding) often requires large graph sketches that cannot be stored or transmitted efficiently. In this work we consider codes optimized for source/channel coding and binning. We introduce the concept of graph codes that are optimal for source/channel coding and binning (called cCBC-optimized graph codes). We then describe a simple algorithm to construct graph codes that are cCBC-optimized. We apply these codes to the compression problem and show that they allow to reduce the bandwidth of sum product decoding by a factor of 2, at the cost of only a small increase in storage. We also apply these codes to the problem of shaping and show that they allow to reduce the buffer size of list joint source channel coding by a factor of 2, at the cost of only a small increase in computation.

Using data from the Neil Gehrels Swift Observatory, we study the spectral and timing properties of the low-mass X-ray binary 4U 1728-34. We fit the continuum as well as photoelectric absorption edges of helium, carbon, and nitrogen using interstellar medium (ISM) models to simultaneously account for background emission and absorption. We model the reflection component using smeared edge functions to determine the global broadband continuum and absorption parameters. For three observations the source exhibited pulsations at a pulse period of 6.67 hr, confirming its neutron star nature. We find the surface gravity of the neutron star is high, and the mass of the compact object is at least 1.6 solar masses. The source exhibited high levels of absorption as well as localized regions of high absorption near 21.0 and 0.25 keV, which we ascribe to the edge absorption of ionized helium and neutral nitrogen, respectively. Using our new spectral results, we discuss previous observations and provide updated interpretations of these observations.

Resolved stellar populations are critical probes of star formation histories and dynamical histories of galaxies. The Orion Nebula Cluster (ONC) provides an important benchmark for testing and developing techniques for interpreting observations of resolved stellar populations, owing to its proximity, well-determined position, luminosity, and age. Several studies have characterized the ONC with deep near-IR and HST data; however, their results are at odds regarding both the presence and nature of a Plummer-like IMF and the actual extinction toward the ONC. In this study, we use X-ray data from the Chandra Orion Ultradev deep survey to study the resolved stellar population in RCW49, a small local galaxy infalling into the Milky Way. We compare our results with the recent study of the ONC and discuss the impact of physical and observational parameters on the derived parameters. We also briefly discuss the possibility of comparing resolved stellar populations seen in different wavelength bands and the potential pitfalls.

The VLT-FLAMES survey of massive stars (VMSS) is aimed at studying the evolution of hot massive stars in the Local Group galaxy the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC). Wind properties and evolution of hot massive stars are key to understand feedback from massive stars in their environment, from the morphological structure of the interstellar medium to the chemical evolution of their host galaxy. Combined high-resolution spectroscopy from VLT-FLAMES allows to determine mass-loss rates from H emission, temperature of the bi-conical winds and thus analyze the evolutionary status of these stars. From the mass-loss rates, Ionic masses can be derived and eventually be used to investigate other properties of the winds, such as ionization degrees and acceleration regions with potential effects on simulations of the feedback into the environment. In this contribution we present the first results on the evolution of hot massive stars in the LMC and the impact of this evolution on the galactic feedback. We confirm previous studies which concluded that the initial mass function (IMF) is top-heavy in the LMC, with respect to the Milky Way. The most massive stars show stronger IMF divergence from the initial mass function (IMF) with increasing age, suggesting that these stars were affected by significant mass-loss episodes. We found more extreme cases of stars with abnormally high nitrogen to carbon (N/C) and nitrogen to oxygen (N/O) abundance ratios, which might be the consequence of a thermohaline mixing process occurring in their winds, an hydrodynamic process taking place in the strong winds of massive stars.

Galaxy clusters have provided key astrophysical constraints over wide wavelength ranges from the radio to the X-ray. Yet despite this success, the process by which clusters assemble their mass remains a central question in modern astrophysics. Analytic theories of cluster assembly (e.g., @rs82) have long been superseded by hydrodynamical cosmological simulations (e.g., @nm04 [@ds08]), which have successfully reproduced key observables such as the cluster luminosity function and temperature function. However, the most massive clusters predicted by these simulations are somewhat under-abundant in comparison to the number of clusters in the real Universe (@k07 [@l06]; see also @s07 for a review). This “cosmic discordance problem” has inspired numerous explanations, including environmental filtering (@w84 [@k84]), cannibalism (@gm02), and massive cluster progenitors (@mm01). However, while these astrophysical theories have been successful in explaining the total amount of mass in clusters, they have not addressed the question of how individual clusters acquire their mass. Recently, we have found that the mass function of globular clusters in nearby galaxies may be directly correlated with the cumulative galaxy light in the cluster vicinity. In contrast to previous explanations that cluster mass is gradually acquired over time through mergers or environmental processes, we have shown that if most massive clusters formed instead by early dissolution of lower-mass systems, then there should be a negative correlation between the cluster mass and cluster light. Indeed, we have found that the data are consistent with the dissolution scenario, such that massive clusters are less common in the Universe and more readily dissolve. However, our results were based on small statistical samples. Here we report on a larger compilation of 22 clusters, for which we have homogeneously derived kinematics and presented a strong evidence for stellar evaporation in 10 of them. We estimate that stellar evaporation is a robust explanation for the dissolution of these clusters, and it naturally explains the mass-light correlation without any further dynamical processes. Thus, we suggest that the stellar evaporation may represent a new mechanism for regulating cluster mass, which has the potential to significantly influence the total amount of mass in clusters in cosmological simulations.

Recent detections of gravitational waves have opened a new window to the extreme Universe. Among the many candidate sources listed by several gravitational wave detectors, a binary system of two supermassive black holes (SMBHs) has been firmly identified as the most plausible candidate for the first detection. Assuming that the coalescing SMBHs have low spin, their gravitational waveforms can be fully described by only two parameters: the mass and the symmetric mass ratio between the two holes. For several hours after the coalescence, during which the gravitational waveform is in the low-frequency band, phenomenological waveform models can accurately describe the signal. However, at later times the signal enters the high-frequency band and the waveform deviations from the TaylorT4 approximation become significant. The behavior of the waveform deviations indicates that the merger product has a spin that is not aligned with the orbital angular momentum of the SMBHs. This Letter reports a search for the radio counterparts of the final few hours of GW170104, the first event observed by Advanced LIGO. The search yielded no detection with the NRAO's Very Large Array at 1.4 GHz, which rules out some suggested explanations for the measurement of the supermassive black hole spin. We place new lower bounds on the fraction of SMBHs with SMBH spin in binary systems.

The photoelectric effect (Maxwell's famous experiment) is among the most well-known and well-understood phenomena in physics. Yet, many students report difficulty learning and understanding this topic, in large part due to the complexity of the equations involved. We developed a four-week curriculum to teach the photoelectric effect that was informed by input from experts in the field, existing textbooks, and student interviews. Students took pre- and post- assessment tests and instructors evaluated students both pre- and post-assessment. Both the pre- and post-test consisted of multiple-choice questions, constructed-response questions, and short essay questions. All students showed significant improvement on the pre-test, on average, and most showed significant improvement on the post-test. Instructors evaluated the curriculum as being successful overall and suggested areas for improvement. In response to student requests, we plan to develop additional modules that address lessons learned from this curriculum.

In this paper, we revisit the issues on Netflow sample and export performance. The traditional measurement of NetFlow performance only considers the number of flow samples, without considering the size of each sample. For example, the exported sample of large packet flow may occupy several hundreds of megabytes, which may cause the surveillance equipments to run out of disk space if the flow sample is not appropriately compressed. Besides, the large flow sample size may also affect the network traffic scheduling of the exporter and even cause certain low-level network applications to fail. In this paper, we propose a new metric Netflow export size, which considers both the size of flow samples and the size of each sample. We conduct several sets of experiments on both virtualized and physical environments. The experimental results show that the Netflow export size can better reflect the actual flow sample size and the impact on other network applications.

We present a detailed chemical and dynamical analysis of five protostellar clusters in intermediate-mass star forming regions, around the sources I18198, I22134, I22134A, I22135, and I22134B. Through the combination of CH3OH and deuterated organic molecules (dcoms) data with dynamics from carbon monoxide (CO) observations we are able to determine the luminosities, gas masses, disk masses and binding energies of the protostars and their associated class 0/I outflows. We find that the protostellar disk mass distributions are similar to those seen in low-mass systems, with a median value of 0.015 M⊙. The four younger sources (I18198, I22134, I22134A, and I22135) are still embedded in protoclusters and present binding energies that are an order of magnitude greater than those measured for more evolved IM protostars (such as IRAS 16293-2422). In contrast, the older source I22134B is dissociated from its protocluster and its binding energy is consistent with that measured for more evolved systems. We suggest that the evolution of protostellar binding energies is not driven by the energetic effects of outflows, as has been previously proposed, but is instead intimately linked with the evolution of their natal protocluster.

Recent X-ray observations with both ʻNewtonʼ and ʻRXTEʼ satellites revealed the presence of a soft excess above the thermal emission of the accretion disk in a significant fraction of Seyfert 1 galaxies. A popular hypothesis to explain this phenomenon is the reprocessing of hard X-rays in Compton-thick material around the central supermassive black hole. However, detailed studies of a few sources with ʻNarrow Field Instrumentsʼ failed to detect such columns of gas. We propose an alternative scenario in which the excess emission originates from electrons in the accretion flow instead of being direct from reprocessing. The electrons will inverse-Comptonize the UV/X-ray light emitted by the disk, and will be cooled through the Moliere process, producing a spectral signature significantly resembling the one observed. The model is consistent with the data from ʻXMM-Newtonʼ and ʻChandraʼ satellites and can provide a satisfactory fit to the soft excess in a large sample of objects.

A search for planets transiting the M dwarf debris disk host AU Mic was performed using publicly available data from the WFIRST satellite and the European Extremely Large Telescope. No planet was found in the AU Mic system, placing an upper mass limit of 45 Mearth around AU Mic within 2.1 AU of the star, and a lower mass limit of 6 Mearth within 0.8 AU of the star. The lack of planets in this system, particularly super-earths, suggests that the system may have undergone dynamical processes that are stripping planetary populations, and/or that AU Mic may have an exceptionally high giant planet formation rate. The star AU Mic is an M4.5V type star located approximately 19.3 light-years from the Earth in the constellation Microscopium. Its debris disk has been spatially resolved with infrared data at 8.28 μm by the Atacama Large Millimeter/Submillimeter Array. In addition, the disk has been observed in thermal emission at shorter wavelengths at 24.5 μm with the European Space Agency's Herschel Space Observatory, at 70.0 μm with the Far-Infrared Surveyor Space Telescope, and at Submillimeter Array baselines of 8-240 m at 1.3 mm. Analysis of these data sets indicates that the disk may be compact with an inner radius of approximately 0.8 AU and an outer radius of 2.1 AU, assuming a gas-to-dust ratio of 100. AU Mic is estimated to be 11.5 billion years old. Several studies have claimed the detection of sub-millimeter planets around AU Mic. An analysis of the ALMA data failed to find any evidence of sub-millimeter emission from exoplanets in the AU Mic system. Conversely, a fit to the visibilities with two planets, one located at 0.93 AU and one at 2.26 AU, provided evidence for the planet at 0.93 AU but not for the one at 2.26 AU, which was attributed to high systematics in the data. Finally, a planet with a minimum mass of 6.3 Mearth was claimed in the spectral line of atomic sodium at 0.84 AU, and the possibility of a second super-Earth with a mass of 8 Mearth was considered but not ruled out. In this paper, I perform a search for planets around AU Mic. I download archival WFIRST data from the NASA Early Access Program, and use the Calar Alto High-Contrast Imaging Poller (CHAIPOD) to perform a pixel-level correlation search. I then download publicly available ESPaDOnS and SOPHIE data to confirm the results. I find no evidence of sub-millimeter emission from planets in the AU Mic system with a 3σ upper limit on the mass of any planet in the system of 6 Mearth. I also search for evidence of habitable zone planets but do not find any

Esprimides Javier, Grigoryants Yaroslav and Trefil Boris. “Weak gravitational lensing in (2+1) gravity.” Physical Review D, 83.8 (July 2010): 084047. doi: 10.1103/PhysRevD.83.084047. In (2+1) gravity, which describes the spatial section of gravity in three dimensions, gravity has two propagating degrees of freedom instead of three. The lensing properties of (2+1) gravity were not studied before. In this paper, we calculate the deflection angle and the shear of light in (2+1) gravity and show that the theory allows for strong lensing, which could be tested with future astronomy. We use the exact solution of the (2+1) gravitational field generated by a point mass as a lens. We obtain an explicit expression for the deflection angle by the point mass in (2+1) gravity. For a point mass in (2+1) gravity the deflection angle is equal to two thirds of the inverse cube of the distance from the point mass to the source. We also calculate the shear of light in (2+1) gravity and show that the theory allows for strong lensing. Our findings can be tested with future astronomy and could be used to test (2+1) gravity.

We carried out the first spectro-astrometric observation of EF Cha and did not observe any significant motion of the warm dust around the star. The COMBO-17 satellite surveyed 1.1 x 1.2 degrees of the northern sky in four bands of the near-infrared corresponding roughly to rest-frame visible light at wavelengths 0.65, 0.85, 1.35, and 2.2 μm. Here we analyze the galaxy morphologies and environment in the Abell 901/902 supercluster at redshift z = 0.33. This structure spans an area of approximately 20 square degrees, contains 775 galaxies with measured redshifts and is among the largest structures yet found at these redshifts. We find that 42% of the members of Abell 901/902 are early-type galaxies, an overdensity compared to the field. Particularly high fractions of early-type galaxies are found in the core of the supercluster at approximately 10 h$^{-1}$ Mpc and in a region of lower mean redshift of 0.31 compared to the rest of the structure at approximately 20 h$^{-1}$ Mpc, suggestive of a recent perturbation. We detect no large scale structure in the density distribution of late-type galaxies, although we note that this may be a consequence of the spatial resolution of the COMBO-17 survey, which is 6.2 h$^{-1}$ kpc at this redshift. We conclude that at least some of the early-type galaxies in Abell 901/902 are a result of recent merging and that the process of morphological transformation of cluster galaxies may be ongoing at this epoch.

Interstellar dust grains are normally observed and studied in the infrared, where their thermal emission helps trace the distribution of dust in our galaxy and in other galaxies. However, a robust measurement of the mass of molecular clouds requires observations at shorter wavelengths, where the emission is not dominated by the thermal dust emission but rather by the much more subtle Rayleigh-Jeans thermal dust emission. Using the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA), we have performed such observations of the Small Magellanic Cloud (SMC). We detect multiple peaks in the thermal dust continuum emission from six regions known to host giant molecular clouds. The derived masses of these molecular clouds are between 430 and 1580 million solar masses, with a total mass of the SMC molecular clouds between 840 and 2380 million solar masses, making up between 25 and 63 per cent of the entire mass of the SMC. These numbers are significantly higher than previous mass estimates that did not account for the clumpiness of the SMC dust emission.

In particle physics, the hierarchy problem is the difficulty of explaining the smallness of the electromagnetic force compared to the stronger nuclear forces. This has led to the suggestion that there is a vast overdensity of vacua in string theory, so the hierarchy problem is analogous to the way that there are many more galaxies than expected within each observable universe. It has been proposed that this supersymmetry (SUSY) may stabilize the weak scale. However, this assumes that all regions of the string landscape are highly connected, which is a natural consequence of current wisdom but has never been proven. I will present two new mechanisms by which this connection can be lost, creating forbidden territories in the string landscape. The first is uplifting a discrete symmetry, which can create a new domain wall at the string scale. This will generically divide the landscape into multiple domains, each with a different pattern of Kähler moduli stabilization and different fractions of the supersymmetry breaking hidden sector gauge group. The second is creating a new light species by deforming the worldsheet theory. This will create domains in the string landscape separated by forbidden zones where closed strings are not able to propagate, leaving the standard model fields localize on a domain wall. I will argue that both of these effects can naturally arise in a class of string theory models with dilaton stabilization, leading to a landscape with a large number of domains, with different patterns of SUSY breaking and moduli stabilization within each domain.

The spin-dependent resonant tunneling characteristics of a double-barrier heterostructures under longitudinal stresses are theoretically investigated based on a 3D effective mass model. The stress-dependent band gaps and Dresselhaus coupling strength are employed to describe the spin-dependent band structures. The theoretical results show that the spin-dependent resonant tunneling probability is highly sensitive to the longitudinal stresses, and two stress-induced resonance peaks can be clearly observed for a positive longitudinal stress, which can be effectively utilized in the device application. Moreover, the symmetry properties of the longitudinal stress-dependent resonant tunneling characteristics are studied in detail. The theoretical results provide a feasible route to explore the spin-dependent transport properties and may be helpful for designing the stress-sensitive resonant tunneling devices. A recent proposal for a physical implementation of the quantum NOT gate [1] has the potential to enable scalable quantum computing using superconducting qubits, opening the door to the construction of a large-scale quantum computer. Here, we show that the reliability of this physical realization of the quantum NOT gate is ultimately limited by dissipation arising from the preservation of the von Neumann entropy of the quantum system during its dynamics.
