Finite-size effects in roughness distribution scaling are discussed for interfaces in statistical physics, social science, and Earth science. The finite-size effects are important when the length scale of interest is comparable or smaller than the system size. This is typically the case for real-world roughness data, where the length scales of interest are typically within one order of magnitude smaller than the system sizes. For such data, the statistical properties may deviate significantly from the corresponding theoretical predictions based on infinitely large systems. In particular, two-point correlations in roughness are shown to be directly proportional to the surface area-to-volume ratio of the system. Examples of applications include but are not limited to evolution of power-law correlations in random growth models, and fitting of power-law roughness scaling to real-world data. Here we consider two well-known examples of the latter application: evolution of roughness correlations in random growth models and fitting of power-law roughness scaling to real-world data. For both applications, the surface area-to-volume ratio plays an important role. First, it determines how far two-point correlation functions can sense the length scale of interest. Second, it modifies scaling exponents that are determined from the slope of correlations at large length scales. These two factors are shown to conspire to yield the finite-size effects on the scaling of the surface area-to-volume ratio with length scale. Two scaling relations for two-point correlations are derived for system sizes from one to infinity. They are shown to be asymptotic to the theoretical predictions for large system sizes. Fitting of power-law scaling to real-world data is found to be particularly susceptible to the finite-size effects. This is because the range of correlation length scales of the data is very narrow, leading to large relative surface area-to-volume ratios. In contrast, theoretical predictions for infinitely large systems break down for the data. This article provides an overview of finite-size effects in scaling relations for real-world data, and points to some common pitfalls that should be avoided.

Nanotubes are carbon allotropes with remarkable physical and chemical properties. Nanotubes can be grown in bundles, where the distance between adjacent nanotubes in a bundle is on the order of 1-10 nanometers. Here we study electromagnetic wave propagation in such tightly packed nanotube bundles. Contrary to predictions based on free space optics, we find that the wave propagation is governed by coupled nanotube Drude responses. These coupled responses are visible as longitudinal and transverse resonances in the scattering matrix spectrum. The Millennium simulation is a large cosmological box which was carried out by the Virgo Consortium between 2000 and 2005. One of its outputs is a catalog of galaxy clusters, which was made public in 2008. I identify 21 red sequences in this catalog, using a technique that matches cluster galaxies’ colours to the location of the most massive member of the cluster. The scatter in the red sequence is 0.17 magnitudes, much lower than previously found, and is only statistically significant in the most dense regions of the clusters. I also show that the observed scatter is consistent with the observed colour-magnitude relation of the member galaxies, suggesting that galaxy evolution may be responsible. The colour-magnitude relation has also been seen in other observational samples, so this may be a more generally applicable explanation for the scatter on the red sequence. A very massive star ends its life as a supernova by shedding its outer layers. These removed layers produce observable light and may be discernible in remnants of the star such as a planetary nebula (PNI). We report evidence for such pre-supernova mass loss in the enigmatic Galactic supernova remnant 3C 58 using images and spectra of its planetary nebula. We measure the mass of the central star and of the layer of ejected material using stellar evolution modeling, and we find pre-supernova mass loss parameters of α = 3.2 ± 0.4% and β = 0.9 ± 0.2, where α is the fraction of the star's mass lost in the stellar wind prior to the supernova explosion and β is the fraction of the star's mass lost in a prior shell ejection prior to the core collapse event. The large measured value of α is in contrast to previous suggestions of mild or no pre-supernova mass loss and suggests that the majority of the star's mass was lost in a prior ejection event. This supports the hypothesis that the progenitor star of 3C 58 was a member of a binary system at some point prior to the supernova explosion.

Using data from the INTErnational Gamma-Ray Astrophysics Laboratory (INTEGRAL), we have studied the gamma-ray emission from the Galactic Centre region. The region is of interest due to its proximity and high concentration of massive black holes and pulsars. We performed a detailed spatial and spectral analysis of the 18 months of public observations covering the region. We find significant emission arising from the central 6 parsec, with spatial structures and spectral variations on both long and short time-scales. In particular, we identify a newly discovered MeV gamma-ray halo surrounding the central core. We investigate the possible origins of the emission, and find that both leptonic and hadronic processes are necessary to explain the data. In the former scenario, we consider both broad-line and narrow-line regions, and find that a combination of simple one-zone models are insufficient to explain the data. In the latter scenario, we consider the possibility of a population of fast transient sources. We find that a physical model in which distant supernova remnants collide with molecular clouds is consistent with the data, and require a dense wind of material from the central supermassive black hole to explain the gamma-ray halo. We discuss the testable implications of this model, and suggest future gamma-ray observations which may distinguish between the two scenarios.

Galaxies in the young universe were first assembled during the Epoch of Reionization (EoR), a period of rapid reconfiguration of the intergalactic medium (IGM) driven by energetic photons from young, highly luminous galaxies. Current observations of the Gunn-Peterson trough in the spectra of high-redshift quasars indicate that the IGM was reionized at $z = 7-8$ and that the process was largely complete by $z = 6$. Large volumes of the high-redshift universe have been observed by the HST and ground-based telescopes, but our understanding of the nature of reionization, especially the space density of galaxies responsible for heating the IGM, has been limited by the small sample of reionization-epoch sources available for study and the large effective volume over which they are observed. This paper presents new, deep, wide-field observations of the SSA22 field obtained with the Mayall 4-meter telescope at Kitt Peak National Observatory that increase the number of observed high-redshift galaxies by more than an order of magnitude and improve the measurement of the volume-weighted quasar ionizing emissivity at $z = 7-8$ by an order of magnitude. These observations demonstrate the feasibility of targeting very high-redshift Ly-alpha emitters (LAEs) with the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST) and demonstrate the power of large telescopes, particularly on northern mid-latitude sites, for extending our understanding of the Epoch of Reionization through improved observations of the most luminous high-redshift galaxies.

Exoplanets are of great interest to scientists, not only due to the scientific value of the information that can be obtained about their physical and orbital properties, but also due to the possibility of finding life-hosting planets. Planets with surface temperatures compatible with the existence of life on Earth, known as habitable planets, can be discovered around the most abundant stars in the galaxy. A particularly attractive group of such planets are those with shorter periods of time between two successive transits across the face of their host star. Such planets are known as "hot Jupiters". The existence of such planets in the habitable zones of their host stars offers the possibility of rapid atmospheric studies using the methods of dynamical atmospheric spectrometry. The atmospheric composition can differ significantly from the composition of the planet's surface due to intense heat and pressure from the sun's light. Knowledge of the surface gravity is thus essential in order to correctly interpret the results of such studies. In this paper, we present a novel technique to accurately determine the surface gravity of transiting extrasolar planets by measuring the duration of the planet's ingress and egress with respect to its host star. We show that the surface gravity of the transiting planet can be determined with an error of less than 2% when the orbital period of the planet and the period of the host star are similar. In the case when the period of the star is half the period of the planet, the error in the surface gravity determination can be as high as 6%, but is always less than 13%. The most important factor influencing the determination of surface gravity is the ratio of the planet's orbital radius to the radius of the star.

In this paper we present a study of the metal-insulator transition in the low-dimensional organic conductor (TMTSF)2FSO3 by means of infrared microspectroscopy. The metal-insulator transition (MIT) in (TMTSF)2FSO3 was first observed in 1981, and has been the subject of extensive studies since. The MIT occurs at Tc = 38 K and is associated with the two-dimensionalization of Fermi-surface sections caused by interlayer coupling. The compound exhibits Shubnikov-de Haas-oscillation-based evidence for 1D metallic behavior below 10 K. The optical conductivity spectrum undergoes a drastic change across Tc, which we attribute to the opening of a Mott-Hubbard gap in the metallicity below Tc. We observe characteristic features of a strongly correlated Mott insulator over a wide frequency range, which is consistent with reported transport, thermodynamic and nuclear magnetic resonance measurements.

Symmetry breaking is an ubiquitous phenomenon in physics. Symmetry breaking in the early universe has profound implications for our understanding of the universe at large. It may provide a mechanism for the generation of density and inhomogeneity perturbations, which can give rise to galaxies and clusters of galaxies via gravitational instability. It may also provide a seed for the development of long-range correlations in the form of Dark Matter. Furthermore, it may provide a way to understand the small density of dark energy relative to the scale of spatial inhomogeneities in the universe. In this paper, we consider the symmetry breaking pattern i.e. the Isometry group of spatially closed FRW universe, and show that it may, in fact, be enlarged to the pseudo-scale invariance (PSI) algebra. This leads to the possibility that Dark Energy may be associated with a scalar field with an exactly conformal coupling to gravity. Furthermore, it is shown that this PSI breaking can also lead to the small density of dark matter as well as the late-time acceleration of the universe. The paper is organized as follows. In the next section, we review the Isometry group of the spatially closed FRW universe and show that it may be enlarged to the PSI algebra. In Sec. 3 we show that this PSI breaking can also lead to the small density of dark matter as well as the late-time acceleration of the universe. The conclusion and some outlook are presented in the last section. The multilayer samples with the approximate composition U0.2Fe0.8 acquired after mild annealing of the as-deposited samples with composition U0.2Fe0.8+x exhibit a ferromagnetic behavior at low temperatures. The Curie temperature Tc is strongly dependent on the annealing parameters. For x = 0.02 the ferromagnetic transition temperature is achieved at temperatures above room temperature, which is an advantage for practical applications. The variation of Tc with x indicates that the observed ferromagnetism is induced by the Fe layer. The effects of post-deposition heat treatments on the magnetic properties of U0.2Fe0.8+x are also investigated. Samples with x = 0.04 show a weak ferromagnetic behavior at low temperatures. The weak ferromagnetism is probably related to the clustering of U5+ ions into small clusters. The saturation magnetization is strongly reduced in comparison with the as-deposited samples. The samples with x = 0.08 exhibit a paramagnetic behavior at low temperatures. This result indicates that strong enrichment of U5+ leads to a magnetic null composition.

The pulsar PSR J1930+1852 in the Crab-like SNR G54.1+0.3 was observed with the satellite XMM-Newton on 2011 April 7. The observation was made following the precise solar ephemeris generated by the PREM model. A search for a sinusoidal modulation in arrival times of the pulsar signal with period equal to the Earth's sidereal day was performed. No such signal was found, but a strict upper limit on the root mean square of the sinusoidal signal with periods equal to the Earth's sidereal day and the sidereal year was established. This limit, depending on the assumed properties of the signal, translates to a bound on the free parameters of possible physics models that could account for the observed properties of the pulsar J1930+1852 and the Crab Nebula in general. The most straightforward explanation of the signals detected in the pulsar timing data so far is the so called ”Shapiro delay” due to the curvature of space-time around the pulsar. A more exotic explanations, such as coupling of the axion field to the neutron, should also be considered.

eternal inflation, de Sitter entropy In physics, entropy is a measure of the disorder of a system. At early times in the history of the universe, the spacetime on sufficiently large scales was conjectured to obey de Sitter geometry, and the entropy was associated with the dimension of the corresponding de Sitter space. However, this conjecture was found to be incorrect on quantum gravity grounds. In particular, it was later shown that quantum corrections to the entropy of de Sitter space actually converge to a finite value. This was taken as a convincing example of the failure of the de Sitter entropy conjecture. In this paper, we will introduce a measure of de Sitter entropy which correctly accounts for quantum gravity corrections. We will then argue that this entropy is exactly equal to the Hubble rate during eternal inflation. We will also show that this entropy matches the Bekenstein–Hawking entropy of de Sitter space, leading us to propose that the latter is an exact quantum gravitational scale. This connection between the entropy of de Sitter space and the rate of expansion of the universe during inflation solves the paradoxes of de Sitter entropy and provides further evidence for the validity of the holographic principle in gravity. The proposed measure of de Sitter entropy, while not being a new fundamental constant of nature, does seem rather surprisingly analogous to the Hubble rate. We speculate on the possible implications of this analogy for the cosmic landscape, the multiverse, and string theory. Thesis: Entropy and the Geometry of Spacetime The entropy of a system is a measure of its disorder. Informally, it is the number of possible states that the system can be in minus one. This intuitively makes sense for systems consisting of many particles, where the number of ways the particles can be arranged is a measure of the system's entropy. In physics, the most common entropy measures are the Gibbs entropy (also known as the Boltzmann entropy) and the von Neumann entropy. They are both defined in terms of the partition function of the system. In general relativity, one defines the entropy of a spatial region to be the surface area of the region's unit normal sphere in a given vacuum geometry, as measured by an observer with appropriate idealizing physical assumptions. There are a number of reasons why this prescription for calculating the entropy is natural. First of all, the normal sphere is a natural generalization of the notion of a point to higher dimensional spacetimes. It is a minimal surface, and minimal surfaces are well-known to be sensitive to topology. In particular, the normal sphere is compact without being topologically a sphere, and this is why the entropy is a diffeomorphism-invariant. Moreover, it is reasonable to require the entropy to be calculated from an ideal observer without feeling too guilty about implicitly making assumptions about the mass and size of the region. Benbow, Hendrik stelling, Aad van der Lugt Link: https://arxiv.org/abs/1809.09212 This paper presents a framework for the automatic extraction of physical laws from joint experimental data. It uses a symbolic deep neural network, trained on symbolic transformations of the data and an explicit CNF neural net to find a most general physical law given a training data set. The framework has been successfully applied to a synthetic data set, and the laws extracted can be shown to correctly describe the data generation process. Two case studies on physical laws extracted from physical experiments are also presented. This framework can be applied to other physical laws, especially those that can be described by partial differential equations, provided that a suitable data set exists.

A multi-wavelength study of z = 3.15 Lyman-alpha emitters in the GOODS South Field is presented. Lyman-alpha emission from galaxies at redshift 3.15 is rare, and is one of the most distant light sources known. With the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), tens of thousands of distant galaxies have been discovered, extending the census of the high-redshift universe to higher redshifts than had been possible with previous techniques. These Lyman-alpha emitters (LAE) allow observation of the high-redshift universe during the "Epoch of Reionization" and can be used to study the process of structure formation. However, significant uncertainties remain about LAEs, including their number density, properties, and role in the Epoch of Reionization. To study these properties, we combine new imaging from the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) with existing imaging from the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) on the Hubble Space Telescope, the Wide Field Camera 3 on the Hubble Space Telescope, Subaru, and the Spitzer Space Telescope. Using these data we search for LAEs and measure their physical properties, comparing them to a control sample of galaxies at low redshift. We find that LAEs at redshift 3.15 are lower mass, less luminous, less strongly clustered, and less likely to be detected in HST bands than galaxies at low redshift. These results are in agreement with expectations for population II galaxies at high redshift, and provide new constraints on the LAE population during the Epoch of Reionization.

Stimulus and noise distributions for optimal information transmission via suprathreshold stochastic resonance (SR) are derived and exemplified for the archetypal nonlinear SR system, the diffusiely coupled FitzHugh-Nagumo model. Optimal information transmission is achieved for the full range of coupling constants when the information-carrying signal is a white noise, that is, it has zero mean. The optimal noise, in contrast, has a non-zero mean, and its variance vanishes as the signal amplitude increases past a critical value. The derived results provide clear design guidelines for maximizing the communication capacity of nonlinear dynamical systems through appropriate signal modulation. Introduction One of the longstanding paradigms of information transmission in nonlinear dynamical systems is stochastic resonance (SR), where a weak, random signal amplifies itself and noise-induced signal fluctuations are enhanced above the level of the signal's mean amplitude.1-3 For over three decades, this counterintuitive phenomenon has been demonstrated experimentally and corroborated with theory for various nonlinear systems, both experimental and theoretical.4-7 More recent studies have focused on information transmission via suprathreshold SR, where the signal is above a certain threshold level.8, 9, 10 The optimal signal structure for suprathreshold SR was shown to be a white noise, i.e., it has zero mean.11, 12 Here, we derive the optimal stimulus and noise distributions for information transmission via suprathreshold SR. Moreover, the optimal noise has a vanishing variance as the signal amplitude increases past a critical value, and the optimal information transmission performance is achieved for the full range of coupling constants. The derived results provide clear design guidelines for maximizing the communication capacity of nonlinear dynamical systems through appropriate signal modulation. In general relativity (GR), one of the principal methods of analyzing weak solutions to Einstein's field equations is the method of nonlinear perturbations, whereby a solution to the equations is analyzed in a perturbative sense around a more simple spacetime. Since the discovery of the Exact Solutions to the Einstein's field equations, a great deal of effort has been made to generalizations of the class of solutions to the nearly-flat and empty-universe variants of the theory. One of the assumptions in the derivation of the solvability conditions for the linearized field equations is that the background geometry is flat. Recently, two of the current authors (JSS and DSR) proposed a framework for analyzing weak solutions to the field equations that include generalizations of the nearly-flat and empty-universe solutions. The central idea in this framework is to relax the assumption of a flat background geometry to one of a curved background geometry. As a result, in addition to the equations satisfied by the perturbation(s) about the curved background, a global constraint on the perturbation is obtained. This constraint, which is a variant of the well-known Bel-Robinson vector field, guarantees that the curvature of the background geometry is propagated by the perturbation(s). In this paper, we provide a detailed exposition of these results for general relativity, general relativity with a negative cosmological constant, and generalizations of these two theories in the presence of a general matter content. We demonstrate the derivation of the perturbed field equations for each of these three theories, as well as the derivation of the global constraint, in both abstract index notation and in the language of tangent frames. This exposition is meant to serve as a tutorial for those not well-versed in general relativity and its applications, as well as as a detailed exposition for those versed in the subject. Furthermore, we have provided multiple appendices with details not central to the exposition.

Recent experimental advances in the field of Bose-Einstein condensates (BECs) enable observation of novel forms of quantum many-body phenomena. Notably, engineering of driven-dissipative quantum systems has led to the observation of quantum phase transitions with light, namely, the Bose-Hubbard model. Integration of BECs with cavity quantum electrodynamics, another milestone in coherent light research, opens up the possibility of realizing effective gauge potentials for quantum particles. Here, we realize both these effects in a single chip device, and observe the formation of chiral supersolids and a chiral spin liquid. We demonstrate that a cavity-BEC platform has many potential applications, ranging from the discovery of new quantum phases to the implementation of quantum simulators and quantum information processing. The article provides an overview of recent experimental results in the field of cavity Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC). The authors demonstrate realization of both effective gauge potentials and the Bose-Hubbard model in a single chip device. Such integrated systems could find applications in quantum simulators and quantum information processing.

Silicon surfaces present many intriguing phenomena owing to the large difference in electronegativity between silicon and oxygen. The regular stepping pattern on the (100) surface is one of the most notable examples, which has been observed for more than seven decades. The (110) surface, on the other hand, presents a similar structure but with a two-fold symmetry, which was first described in 1952 and termed the “densité échelonnée” (“stepped array of chains”). Due to its highly faceted shape, the (110) surface has been the subject of many recent studies. Here, we report high-resolution low-energy electron microscopy experiments that reveal a detailed reconstruction model for vicinal (100) and (110) surfaces. In addition to the well-known surface step density-wave pattern, we observe facet-induced bending of the steps and chains at the triple points between steps, leading to the formation of “V”-shaped steps. Using a simple model, we are able to explain the main features of this unusual reconstruction. The information we provide here should facilitate future experiments and simulations on these interesting surfaces.

The Infrared Array Camera (IRAC) and the Multi-band Imaging Photometer (MIPS) were mounted on the Spitzer Space Telescope to study the physical properties of galaxies by observing their spectral energy distributions (SEDs). The data obtained by these telescopes can be used to study the Star Formation Rate (SFR) of galaxies by using different algorithms to measure their Mid-Infrared (MIR) SEDs. In this work, the calibration of these algorithms for the MIR SFR indicators is presented. The data used in this study was obtained from the Hi-GAL, GAMA and PACSplus surveys. A Large Sample Study (LSS) of these data was performed to find the SFR Indicators with the highest reliability. The data was analysed using three methods: 1) the neural network of the Random Forest algorithm, 2) the Bayesian Photometric Penalisation and 3) the Mean T Y Model. The results obtained show that the reliability of the measurements of the SFR Indicators using the MIPS 24 μm filter is better than that of the MIR SFR Indicators derived using the IRAC Channels 1, 2, 3 and 4 and the MIPS 24 μm filter. We present the first complete simulations of the collisional evolution of Kuiper Belt (KB) objects (KBOs). We calculate the dynamical evolution of test particles placed in heliocentric orbit typical of those of the KB objects Eris, Sedna, and Orcus. From these simulations, we calculate the physical evolution of these objects' surfaces, collisional lifetimes, geology, lithologies, compositions, and dynamical membership in the Parenago segregation category. We also calculate how the spectra of these objects would change if they had differentiated. The majority of the observed colors, reflectance spectra, and visible-light spectra of the KB objects we studied are the result of static clouds of regolith superimposed on underlying differentiated surfaces. We suggest that visible-light spectroscopic observations of such objects might allow discrimination between these models, if, for example, albedo or feature spacing data were available. In this work, we consider a multiple-antenna fading channel with a quantized precoding matrix. The transmitter uses linear precoding to send signals to a receiver with multiple antennas. To illustrate the capacity of this channel, we first consider the non-precoding case and characterize the capacity with the signal-to-quantization-noise ratio (SQNR), where the quantization is imposed at both the transmitter and the receiver. We then consider the case with zero-forcing (ZF) precoding and characterize the capacity for two different scenarios: when the SQNR is large, i.e., with high-precision quantization; and when the SQNR is small, i.e., with low-precision quantization. Through numerical results, we show that both the non-precoding and ZF precoding cases achieve similar performance for high SQNR, but that precoding can significantly increase the capacity for low SQNR.

We present new radio observations of 38BAL quasars selected from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) spectroscopic database. The radio observations include very long baseline array (VLBA) observations at 5, 8, 14.5, and 22 GHz, plus data from the Faint Images of the Radio Sky at Twenty-centimeter survey (FIRST), the NRAO VLA Sky Survey (NVSS), and the Texas Sydney University Molonglo Sky Survey (TSSDM). Approximately 90% of the sample has been detected by these surveys at radio wavelengths, and 37 have upper limits at longer wavelengths. We perform a thorough analysis of the radio through X-ray spectral energy distributions (SEDs) of the sample and compare these to optical and X-ray data. In most cases, we do not detect radio cores, and we analyze the emission from extended components only. We find that approximately two-thirds of the sources have a rising or flat radio SED at frequencies below 10 GHz, while the remaining one-third have a declining or heavily inverted radio SED. Many of the sources have X-ray absorption significantly in excess of the Galactic value. We argue that an unusual orientation relative to the radio-loud nucleus and/or jet is responsible for the radio emission in the flat- or rising-spectrum subsample, and the steep spectra of this subsample are more likely due to beaming caused by the relativistic jets. We consider the implications of our results for high-energy emission in these sources and note that the flat- or rising-spectrum subsample is a good candidate for future radio observations in order to test whether Doppler beaming plays a significant role in their radio emission.

We present the results of a search for diffuse optical streams in a sample of 71 low-redshift ($z < 0.2$) groups and clusters of galaxies. We used deep imaging of a 1.7 square degree field around the south Galactic pole with the GRavitational lOng Survey Telescope Array (GRAvaroo), which is composed of five small optical telescopes. After careful application of various data quality filters, we identify three candidate systems with coherent, faint, linear streams of stars consistent with a stream-like configuration of the disrupted satellite galaxies. The brightest of these three candidates, with a heliocentric recessional velocity of 14,200 km/s, is consistent with other confirmed satellites of the Milky Way at lower heliocentric velocities, supporting its identification as a dark-matter-dominated stream. The other two candidates, with heliocentric recessional velocities of 24,300 km/s and 32,300 km/s, have very low satellite galaxy contamination and can each be plausibly associated with an identified accretion event in the fossil record, suggesting that the streams have physical properties similar to those of previously-observed cosmological streams. If confirmed, these systems would represent the lowest-redshift galaxies containing streams of stars arising from the disruption of satellite galaxies and would represent a record of some of the most massive accretion events in the local volume. These results suggest that wide, faint, linear features may be a common property of galaxy groups and clusters at low redshift, even in the absence of massive central galaxies, and that these systems may represent important constituents of the overall cosmological stream population.

The massive stellar cluster Westerlund 1 is one of the closest analogues of a typical starburst galaxy. Located some 20,000 light-years away in the constellation of Carina (the pointy car), Westerlund 1 is home to hundreds of massive stars, including several of the most massive known in the galaxy. However, despite its proximity, Westerlund 1 has remained a challenging target for observation because it is embedded in a dense, neutral environment created by the combined effects of its own powerful ionizing radiation field and the deeper ultraviolet light produced by its massive stars. Using data from the Herschel Space Observatory, we report on the detection of a small amount of cooling radiation from this environment—the first direct evidence of the small amount of gas that does exist within the core of Westerlund 1. This, together with measurements of the dispersion of its member stars’ proper motions, allows us to put an upper bound on the cluster’s distance of between 12 and 18 kpc, well within the estimated 20-30 kpc diameter of the ionizing radiation region. Our findings provide constraints on the initial mass of Westerlund 1’s most massive stars and the age of its youngest members, and support the notion that Westerlund 1, despite its proximity, may be very similar to other young, massive star clusters that have been observed in the local universe.

Galaxy clusters are the largest known structures in the universe, containing hundreds or even thousands of galaxies. Despite their importance, it is not easy to study the large-scale behaviour of cluster galaxies. Most of the time one has to resort to studying individual galaxies or small samples. A promising approach is to model the overall galaxy light distribution and use the resulting model to fit the light of distant galaxies. Such an approach was proposed by Falco et al. in 1987 and implemented on large datasets by Gonzalez et al. in 2002. Since then, several improvements and adaptations to different galaxy samples have been proposed. We present the dataset of early-type galaxies in the WINGS clusters, a multi-wavelength catalogue with morphological classification, HST imaging and extensive follow-up data. The dataset has been modelled and fitted using three different techniques: non-parametric SFH modelling, bulge+disk decomposition and semi-parametric Boxy4 modelling. The results indicate that both star formation history and bulge prominence have varied during the lifetime of clusters.

Modules over operads and their relationship to functors have been the subject of much recent work. The most precise of these results, a strong form of the Yoneda lemma, equates modules over an operad with functors from that operad to the category of abelian groups. This result relies on work of Smith and others in the derivation of a module over a PROP from a functor into the category of chain complexes. The method of proof relies on the structure of PROPs as universal algebras. We show that a version of the Yoneda lemma holds for small, skeletal operads, including those corresponding to stable, homology theories. A simple proof of the skeletal Yoneda lemma applies to any operad in well-generated monoids in spaces. This generalizes the classical theorem of Barratt and Eisenbud that coherent rings correspond to associative, unital monoids in spaces. The skeletal version of the Yoneda lemma implies the more precise form. We give a number of examples of skeletal operads arising in homology theories, including K-theory, connective K-theory, extended K-theory, complex bordism, and motivic homology theories.

In this paper, we present a communication model for adaptive service provisioning in hybrid wireless networks that consist of both licensed and unlicensed spectrum bands. Lithium-like ions have been widely used as tests of quantum electrodynamics (QED) calculations due to their simple structure. In this work QED calculations of the 2p1/2-2s and 2p3/2-2s transition energies and the ground-state hyperfine splitting in lithium-like scandium are presented. Theory and experiment agree to within 4.2% and 5.2% for the two transition energies and the ground-state hyperfine splitting, respectively. The 2s2 2p(1/2)2p(3/2) and 2s2 2p(3/2)3s bound-states energies of lithium-like scandium were calculated using the multiconfiguration Dirac-Hartree-Fock (MCDHF) theory including all single and double electron relativistic, quantum electrodynamic (QED) and electron correlation corrections. The 2p1/2-2s and 2p3/2-2s transition energies and the ground-state hyperfine splitting were estimated by combining the MCDHF energies with the relativistic many-body perturbation theory and all order charge delocalization correction methods. In this paper, we review some of the most recent results obtained in our laboratory concerning the calculation and measurement of thermal Casimir force between real materials. Casimir forces are long-range, quantum electromagnetic forces that arise from the modification of the zero-point energy spectrum of the quantum electromagnetic field due to the presence of boundaries. Forces of this kind play an important role in nanotechnology, because they can influence the equilibrium position of molecules or mechanical components and may provide a useful mechanism of actuation. The latter aspect is of special interest in developing new micromechanical devices. At finite temperatures, there are two distinct contributions to the Casimir energy, the so-called ideal or thermal term and the nonideal or quantum term. The ideal term is obtained by simply multiplying the zero-point energies of the quantum electromagnetic field in the respective regions. The nonideal term, on the other hand, accounts for the changes in the zero-point energy induced by the presence of boundaries. At room temperature, the ideal term is many orders of magnitude smaller than the nonideal term and may therefore be neglected. At low temperatures, on the other hand, the nonideal term becomes increasingly larger than the ideal term and may even change the direction of the force acting between two objects. This phenomenon is known as thermal capt. The topic of this paper is the calculation and measurement of the thermal Casimir force between real materials. In particular, we will focus on two prototypical systems, namely, two parallel plates made of gold and covered with a layer of teflon, and a crossed grid of stainless steel wires mounted on a copper plate. In order to calculate the thermal Casimir force, we use the so-called Green's function method. The experimental setup for measuring the thermal Casimir force is based on the recent invention of W. J. Kim and H. M. Chan of the Stanford Research Systems Inc. (SRS). This setup is able to measure the force with a very high precision. We have performed measurements of thermal Casimir force between the two parallel plates and between the crossed grid and the plate. We have also calculated the thermal Casimir force between the two parallel plates using different theoretical models, including the so-called proximity force approximation. We found excellent agreement between the measured and calculated values of the thermal Casimir force.

In this paper we describe the action of the absolute Galois group on the set of connected components of the moduli space of surfaces of general type. We show that this action is faithful and topological, i.e. does not preserve the underlying schemes. Let X be a smooth projective variety over a field k. The absolute Galois group of k, written Gal(k), acts on the set of connected components of the Hurwitz scheme of models of X over finite fields. We show that this action is faithful if and only if X is not rational. We then show that the action of Gal(k) on the set of connected components of the Hurwitz scheme is topological if and only if the Picard number of X is at most 1, if and only if the canonical bundle of X is trivial. We apply this result to describe the action of Gal(k) on the set of connected components of the moduli space of surfaces of general type.

Four-fermion interaction models are very attractive theories with diverse phases. In particular, the Gross-Neveu model in 1+3D (1 spatial + 3 temporal dimensions) with a positive mass parameter has a phase with spontaneous symmetry breaking. Its order parameter is a difermion condensate. In this model the phase transition is of second order. In 2D the model has a phase with fermion condensation and a phase with dimerization. The model in 3D with a positive mass parameter also has a phase with difermion condensation, which is, however, of first order. On the negative mass square plane, the system has a U(1) symmetry with a Goldstone mode. In 2D, the model has a phase with condensation of Jordan wigners and in 3D it has a phase with condensation of bosonic dimers. In this work, we study a general 2-4D model with four-fermion interaction. We find that in 2D this model also has a phase with difermion condensation, and on the negative mass square plane it has a U(1) symmetry with a Goldstone mode.

In recent years, space exploration has brought humanity closer to answering the age-old question of whether there is life on other planets. One of the main challenges for exoplanet hunters is identifying the chemical signatures of possible life on planets outside our solar system. A potential telltale biosignature is a cirrus cloud with a high albedo, or reflectivity, which could bounce light from a planet’s surface into space and cast a dark shadow on the planet’s surface. Here we report the gamma-ray albedo of the moon, a measure of its gamma-ray absorption cross section above 30 MeV, from a sample of gamma-ray lines from 1 MeV to 1 TeV obtained by the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope. We find that the albedo of the moon is around 0.32, consistent with estimates based on soil composition. This high albedo value is due to the fact that the lunar surface is covered with anorthosite rock formed by the crystallization of volcanic ashes from the impacts of meteorites 3.9 billion years ago. Given the vast number of potentially habitable planets in our galaxy, the gamma-ray albedo of the moon could serve as an efficient method to identify biosignatures on planets orbiting other stars.

Polarization states of the primordial gravitational waves (GWs) remain encoded in the temperature and polarization anisotropies of the cosmic microwave background (CMB). To probe these states, we introduce a novel statistic, the Stokes parameter variance (SPV), and develop new methods to analyze future cosmic microwave background (CMB) observations. We show that an experiment with sky coverage of 5,000 square degrees and noise level of ~0.01 σ(SPV) can probe the (spin up ⟂ ↗, spin down ⟂ →) states with a significance of 5 σ. This can be extended to the 24-dimensional parameter space of (⟂ ↗, ⟂ →, ⟂ ∥, ⟂ ⊥) by adding low resolution CMB polarization observations. We demonstrate the robustness of our method by simulating the gravitational wave foreground and showing that the SPV measurement is largely insensitive to these foregrounds. We apply our method to ongoing CMB temperature and low resolution polarization observations and place constraints on the amplitudes of the spin-2 operators generated by gravitational waves in the estimated skies. Our approach is entirely data-driven and does not make any prior assumptions about the theory or the foreground nature of the observations. We provide an easy to use publicly available software package for polarization estimation from future CMB observations.

Longitudinally inhomogeneous coronal loops are known to undergo torsional oscillations when the longitudinal twist exceeds a critical value. This Letter shows that the twist evolves as a function of time and forms longitudinal inhomogeneous kinks that are then twisted. This process can explain many features of torsional oscillations that have been observed. This model can be used to understand the dynamics of twisted coronal loops in the solar atmosphere. Longitudinal inhomogeneity is essential to the formation of kinks. An analytical kink solution is found and numerical results are provided for both the kink evolution and the oscillation of twist. A twisted kink loop is simulated and shown to reproduce many features of observed torsional oscillation loops. The oscillation period is sensitive to the half-length, thickness and twist of the loop. These results may have applications in solar magnetohydrodynamics and in the interpretation of solar UV bursts. Longitudinally inhomogeneous coronal loops undergo torsional oscillations when the longitudinal twist exceeds a critical value. This critical twist increases with the longitudinal loop inhomogeneity. A twisted kink loop is a fundamental solution of the equilibrium twist evolution. By developing, we mean twisting more than is necessary to satisfy the twist evolution equation. The twist evolves as a function of time and forms longitudinal inhomogeneous kinks that are then twisted. This process can explain many features of torsional oscillations that have been observed.

In August 2022, a hitherto unnoticed dwarf galaxy passed near the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC). Optical observations by the Pan-STARRS1 telescope, which is located on Haleakala on Maui, Hawaii, revealed a massive globular cluster, similar in colour and magnitude to the LMC, trailing behind the dwarf. Spectroscopic follow-up with the Keck I and II telescopes showed the globular cluster to be extremely metal-poor, with an average metallicity of only 5% of the solar value. The only other known object of such low metallicity is the Small Magellanic Cloud. The only possible explanation for the formation of this object is the infall of a relatively massive galaxy in the early stages of its evolution. We conclude that this object is the remains of a galaxy nucleus that has been stripped of its gas and is currently being assimilated into the LMC. This remarkable object shows that galaxies can interact with one another in unexpected ways.

We present a detailed study of the physical properties of a sample of 50 MgII absorbers at z = 2.5 (1+z = 2.5), selected from the SSA22 field based on visual and model fits to their spectra, and observed with the FMOS and GES at the Subaru Telescope. By fitting the Mg II and metal lines in the quasar spectra with synthetic spectra we measure their physical properties: gas phase metal abundances, velocity widths and internal gas pressures, the latter of which we utilize in combination with the Mg II column densities to calculate the total mass of the gas halos. We compare our measurements to predictions from high-resolution, large N-body/hydrodynamical simulations, and find good agreement for the ensemble properties of the sample, and weak to no evolution in the individual absorber properties with redshift. However, we find that the absorbers have an effective radius of b(eff) = 1.2 ± 0.3 physical kpc at z = 2.5, an order of magnitude smaller than predicted from recent results for the relationship between Mg II absorber properties and dark matter halo masses. We argue that this discrepancy may be reconciled by taking into account the effect of feedback and galactic feedback in the simulations, which can significantly reduce the extent of the galaxy halo dark matter envelopes.' We also present weak lensing measurements of the mass distribution in the same field using optical imaging from the Hyper Suprime-Cam (HSC) survey. We find no significant correlations between absorber properties and the positions of individual galaxies, nor of the dark matter halos themselves, nor of the HSC-inferred dark matter distribution. However, we do find that the effective radius of the gas halos measured from absorption are weakly but significantly correlated with the mass of the corresponding dark matter halos; this correlation has been observed previously in simulation, and is consistent with theories of hydrodynamical instability induced by cold, low-density gas accretion onto dark matter halos. Overall, we find good agreement between absorption-based and lensing-based halo mass measurements, suggesting that observed Mg II absorbers likely trace the most highly biased regions of the underlying dark matter distribution, and that further studies of these objects can be used to study structure formation and the circum-galactic medium.

A binary alloy is a chemical mixture of two or more different elements in definite proportions. They are commonly defined as a system with non-overlapping, homogeneous volume fractions occupied by two or more species of elements. Atomic arrangements and compositions lead to different properties. In this paper we study the case where the first species is dimers and the second species is monomers (usually represented by A). We show that upon dimer adsorption at zero temperature, the system undergoes a percolation transition at a specific concentration. This percolation concentration increases when the temperature increases. We argue that this interplay is related to the balance between two processes: i) dimers cover the lattice forming aggregates ii) these aggregates jam increasing the number of sites unfilled. We solve this problem using a functional renormalization group approach, valid for low concentrations of dimers. We compute several critical exponents and discuss the universality classes that the phase diagram belongs to.

Graphene, a monolayer of carbon atoms with a remarkable atomic structure, has attracted immense interest recently because of its diverse extraordinary properties, such as extremely high carrier mobility, which leads to the achievement of the record high carrier mobility of ~26,000 cm2 V-1 s-1 in monolayer graphene. One major drawback in the practical applications of graphene is the lack of band gap, which severely restricts its utilization in energy related devices. Traditionally, semiconductors are utilized to manufacture electronic devices such as transistors, solar cells, and LEDs due to the abundance of silicon and the highly effective crystalline structure of silicon based semiconductors. The lack of band gap in graphene has led to investigations into several methods to introduce a band gap in graphene. Recently, it has been theoretically shown that an alternative approach to introduce a band gap in graphene, which is without the need for any external constraint or reagents, is to introduce a periodic potential through modulating the potential landscape on the surface of graphene with an external gate electrode. One such method is to introduce a periodic electric field, which can be achieved through Coulomb drag, where one layer of charge carriers is subjected to an electric field and a second layer of charge carriers is polarized in the opposite direction of the first layer. Coulomb drag has been observed in two-dimensional electron gases (2DEGs) in semiconductor systems with the presence of a high concentration of electrons and holes in a material with a band gap, such as GaAs, InAs, or GaN. Therefore, Coulomb drag is a viable approach to introduce a band gap in graphene. In this work, we observe Coulomb Drag in graphene, the first observation of Coulomb Drag in a 2D material system. By growing a thin layer of hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) on top of a synthesized graphene monolayer, we can isolate and control the charge carriers in one layer from the other via structural electric field screening. An electric field is then applied between the separated layers and is observed to produce charge separation in the layer subjected to the electric field. This charge separation induces a static polarisation in the other layer via the Kapitza-Dirac effect. The induced static polarisation is observed via capacitance measurements on the separated layers. We observe positive drag, where the charge carrier layer with applied electric field has a higher charge density and negative drag, where the charge carrier layer with polarisation has a lower charge density. Coulomb Drag in graphene is successfully observed for the first time and opens the door to study a material with unique properties such as graphene in a fully tunable bandgap environment, h-BN.

The spectrum of ultra-high-energy cosmic rays (UHECRs) is typically assumed to follow a power-law, dN/dE = K E-α, where α is the spectral index and K is a normalization constant. One popular mechanism for accelerating cosmic rays to such high energies is the shock acceleration process, where particles scatter back and forth between longitudinal waves until they cross a relativistic shock at which point they attain a non-zero energy corresponding to the jump in the relativistic downstream speed across the shock. Consequently, a popular method for constraining the cosmic-ray power spectrum is by observing the flux ratio of UHECRs above and below the Greizen-Zatsepin-Kuzmin (GZK) cutoff. However, such a cutoff is not observed in the flux of UHECRs and its absence has led to the development of possible solutions involving new beyond-Standard-Model physics, such as neutron decaying to electron-antineutrinos. One such beyond-Standard-Model scenario is that cosmic rays are produced via the decay of dark matter particles, which can be motivated by the recent hints for dark matter provided by numerous cosmological, astrophysical and laboratory observations. In this paper we consider the recently proposed model that the dark matter particles are bosons with zero spin, and thus are maximally correlated, and that the decay channel is to standard model particles via a mediation channel involving a real scalar field. We show that under these assumptions the energy in cosmic rays produced via this decay channel cannot explain the observed fluxes above the GZK cutoff. Furthermore, this scenario is excluded by recent observational results from the Pierre Auger Observatory and Telescope Array, which are able to detect a flux of UHECRs at Earth with an overall spectral index of 4.6 and a cutoff at around 56 Ee+19 eV. We therefore conclude that this scenario is disfavoured by existing observations.

Recent surveys such as ZENI, POINT-MAD and MOA have been extremely useful in detecting planets around other stars, particularly super earths and Neptune mass planets. A very interesting aspect of these surveys has been the use of the gravitational microlensing effect to search for planets around other stars. Microlensing occurs when a star passes in front of an object such as a star or a star system and the light of the background star is affected by the passage of the foreground object. If a planet is passing in front of the background star, the planet will exert a small but significant gravitational force on the light of the background star and this will cause a deviation from the straight line trajectory of the light path. The angular separation of the background and foreground objects as well as the time scale of the event are determine by the size of the planet and the distance of the planet from the star. These surveys have used the observations of lensing events to search for planets with a wide range of masses and distances from the host star. These surveys have also been successful in detecting planets that are at the same distance from their star as the Earth is from the Sun, i.e. between 0.01 and 1 AU. This in turn has lead to the development of new strategies for the direct imaging of planets. The results of these surveys have led to the detection of planets around a wide range of host stars including red dwarf stars which are common in the galaxy but have very low masses and small radii. Planets play an important role in the evolution of systems including our own Solar System. The detection of planets outside of our Solar System and in other solar systems allows us to determine the distribution of planets as a function of distance from their star and also the characteristics of the planet. In this paper we review the results of these surveys and discuss the advantages and disadvantages of the microlensing method for detecting planets.

Personal archives hold a unique record of our lives and experiences. Often these collections are a mix of mementos, documents, and computer files that reflect different points in time and generate from different applications or sources. Providing a seamless and secure experience for the user has been a key challenge for archival service providers. In this paper, we propose a service model for personal archives that is complementary to existing cloud and backup offerings. In our model, users retain ownership and control of their data, and service providers offer access to files based on established security criteria. In return, users are paid for the services they use. In this way, service providers can utilize data while allowing users to monetize their assets, benefitting both parties. To demonstrate our approach, we have integrated with a File-hosting service to provide access to a sample of user files. Our preliminary evaluation suggests that users are able to access their data quickly and securely through this interface, with the service generating significant revenue for the host. We also discuss key considerations and challenges for this model, and highlight opportunities to further integrate with security services, enable access via Web browsers, and promote user privacy. This work was sponsored by the Institute for Advanced Technology & Public Policy (IATP) at George Mason University. The digital assets of individuals are growing increasingly large in volume and diverse in source and type, including documents, images, videos, and computational artifacts created by individuals and their interacting with digital systems. Many individuals would like to ensure the availability and accessibility of their digital assets into the future, and would prefer to monetize their use of these assets while they are still accessible. A challenge for service providers is to assist individuals in meeting these goals while maintaining the privacy and security of the data and providing a sustainable business model. We present a model that enables individuals to own and monetize their data while providing a seamless, secure experience for the user. Service providers will be able to access data while meeting security criteria established by the user, and users can generate revenue for the services they use. We present our approach to integrating with a cloud storage service to demonstrate the compatibility and security of this model. We also discuss additional considerations necessary for fully integrating with security services and show preliminary revenue results. We conclude by discussing the potential challenges and opportunities for this model and identify next steps to address these challenges and develop this idea into a sustainable business. Personal archives, like those of Alan Turing or Edward Snowden, provide a unique perspective on current affairs. The long-term accessibility and security of these collections is increasingly a concern. Encryption methods improve annually, but remain cumbersome to use and are vulnerable to motivated or unknowledgeable attackers. In addition, the quantity and variety of digital assets generated by individuals grows increasingly large and complex. Personal archives must adopt a user-centric approach that allows owners to control their data and ensure its accessibility while meeting the unique needs of each archive. Nova explosions are powered by the rapid conversion of hydrogen to helium via the pp chain. The reaction rates in simulations are set by fitting to experimental data from the sun, but how well do these rates represent nova explosions, which can occur in a vastly different environment? I find that changes in these rates can alter the amount of explosive hydrogen produced, the amount of fallback, and the amount of radioactive nickel synthesized. In some cases, the nova fails to explode at all. The rates may need to be adjusted to better represent nova explosions, and I propose a simple method to do so. I also analyze how the explosion dynamics are affected by the chosen reaction rates. Increasing the hydrogen reaction rate too much increases the amount of explosive hydrogen produced and thus the strength of the explosion. In contrast, decreasing the hydrogen reaction rate too much decreases the amount of explosive hydrogen produced. Decreasing the hydrogen reaction rate too much leads to weak explosions that do not achieve nuclear statistical equilibrium. Examining these rates reveals that there is an optimal hydrogen reaction rate that results in a good explosion with the correct amount of explosive hydrogen, amount of fallback, and amount of radioactive nickel.

We present an analytical model for the self-similar scaling relations between the Sunyaev-Zel'dovich (SZ) effect signal and the physical properties of the astrophysical systems they are derived from. The model considers the projection effect in the spatial structure of the systems and takes into account the hydrostatic bias caused by the luminous or total mass distribution. We apply our model to interpret the SZ profiles obtained with the Atacama Cosmology Telescope (ACT) and show that the ACT-derived SZ surface brightness profiles can be well fitted by the self-similar form if certain scaling relations are imposed. We also show that there are systematics in the SZ measurements due to the limited signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and beam-smoothing effect and propose an empirical method to reduce these systematics. We test our method on numerical simulations and show that the self-similar scaling relations can be violated if the hydrostatic bias is not properly taken into account. We apply our model to the Horizon-AGN simulation and demonstrate that the typical magnitude of the violation of the scaling relations is around 40%. We also show that the amplitude of the scaling relations can be used to measure the bias factor between the total mass and the gas mass, which can be used to calibrate the flux bias correction for SZ effect. All the scaling relations obtained with our model are independent of the cosmological model, which can be used to put robust cosmological constraints with SZ effect data.

The high energy emission of GRO J1655-40 as revealed with INTEGRAL spectroscopy of the 2005 outburst is described. This well-known black hole X-ray binary is a system composed of a Neutron Star primary orbiting a black hole of 18 Meters in close orbit (13-31 R_s) every 2.87 hours. It is suspected that disk accretion onto the neutron star occurs in this system, as evidenced by its spectral class of Z-source, which is characterized by having strong, sometimes regular, neutron star high-speed winds. These winds are likely due to the transfer of energy from the accretion disk onto the neutron star. The 2005 outburst of GRO J1655-40 was detected with the INTEGRAL observatory on Jan. 28, 2005, and reached a maximum on Feb. 24. The work presented here focuses on the high energy spectrum of GRO J1655-40 over this time period. The major result of this work is the discovery of acutoff powerlaw component in the high energy spectrum of GRO J1655-40, with a flux contribution of approximately 50% over nearly 3 decades in energy. This component is not commonly observed in X-ray binaries, and therefore its discovery with INTEGRAL represents a new paradigm for high energy production in these systems. The cutoff powerlaw component is believed to be an extension of the accretion disk blackbody component which is often seen in black hole X-ray binaries, and is generally thought to be the signature ofNETWORK GAMMA RAYS radiated by the inner part of an accretion disk around a black hole. The discovery of a cutoff powerlaw in this system, with a neutron star at its core, represents a new paradigm for high energy production in black hole X-ray binaries, and may indicate that disk accretion is not the only form of high energy production in these binaries. It is possible that this component is the result of a new form of high energy production unique to this system, which may be a result of the strong neutron star winds. This may be a promising area for exploration with further, more detailed analysis of these data.

In quantum mechanics, the angular momentum (AM) and linear momentum (PM) operators have a spectrum of eigenvalues that is far more extensive than that allowed by classical Physics. For example, the eigenvalues of the square of the total AM operator in a given quantum mechanical state are proportional to the total nuclear spin, a property with theoretically unlimited resolution. In addition, the eigenvalues of the square of the total linear momentum operator in a given quantum mechanical state are equal to the square of the reciprocal of the reduced Planck's constant, a physically observable property with theoretically unlimited precision. Since these quantities are numerically equal to, respectively, the total AM and total PM of the quantum state, this work concludes that quantum mechanics does in fact adhere to the AM and PM properties expected from classical Physics. These extraordinary results are the consequence of rigorous mathematical theorems from the field of Quantum Mechanics, which state that the eigenvalues of these operators are theoretically unbounded. In this study, the dust distribution in edge-on galaxies is analyzed using data from radiative transfer fits of V and K'-band images. We find that the relative distributions of stars and dust follow a approximately lognormal distribution. The lognormal shape of the dust distribution is consistent with that of the distribution of dust emission in our own Galaxy, and provides an empirical relation between the total amount of dust and the ratio of dust to stellar light in a galaxy. We show that this relation is independent of the radial dependence of the ratio of dust to stellar light, and hence provides a simple method for estimating the total amount of dust in a galaxy. We also find that the scale height of dust is smaller than that of stars, and that the dust scale height decreases with increasing distance from the mid-plane of the galaxy. The radial dependence of the dust scale height is consistent with that predicted by simple models of dust distribution in galactic disks. Finally, we find that the dust-to-stellar-light ratio increases with increasing absolute magnitude of the galaxy.

In this work we consider a generalization of classical repeated games, called asynchronous games. In an asynchronous game, there is no requirement that the players observe the history of past actions, but rather each player’s action only depends on the current state and the current action of the player. Asynchronous games allow for more general interactive strategies than their classical synchronous counterparts. One setting that has been studied extensively is that of mixed-motive, or Hawk-Dove, games. Here, one player (the Hawk) can choose to do nothing, and the other player (the Dove) must decide between two actions. In this case, it has been established that mixed strategies are optimal for the Dove, i.e. the Always Defect policy is a Nash equilibrium. Here we introduce a game in which there is only a single player, and the player can choose to do nothing, participate in the game, or switch between these two actions infinitely often. We show that such a player has an almost sure optimal strategy, i.e. that they will play a best-response against any strategy that the opposite player may employ. We also show that there is an initial profile for which the payoff of the first-player is strictly less than that of the second-player. In particular, this implies that the first-player has an optimal almost-sure strategy in this initial profile. We believe this example to be of independent interest, as it shows that a.s. optimality can be achieved without the requirement of alternation of plays.
