This method of traversing the wormhole requires that the Euclidean path integral be performed across the wormhole, with the traversal switched on at the end of the wormhole and switched off at the end of the Euclidean universe. Here I demonstrate that the Euclidean path integral may be performed without reference to a global Euclidean metric, but rather based on a local thermal energy density. Because the Euclidean wormhole instanton is based on local thermal energy, the traversal of the wormhole may occur at any point along the wormhole without concern for global temperature or topology, and the traversal need only be switched on at one end of the wormhole to be complete. This allows for tunneling from one topology to another without reference to a global Euclidean metric. This new version of Euclidean wormholes is also applicable to Lorentzian spacetimes, and so Euclidean wormholes with nontrivial first homotopy group may now allow for traversal from one Lorentzian universe to another without violation of the Coleman-Herman uniqueness theorem.

The merging cluster system ESO137-001 is composed of two subgroups in the process of merging, the larger one Abell 3627 with a redshift of 0.1 and the smaller one ESO137-001 at a redshift of 0.0174. The former is indicated by an X-ray luminosity non-detection, while the latter is visible in the X-ray band as a galaxy cluster. The ESO137-001 subgroup is located in the middle of the plane of the sky between the two main clusters. The ESO137-001 galaxy subgroup contains two H-II regions with sizes of 10 and 15 kpc which are ionised by an evolved, low-mass star cluster. They are also associated with extended H-alpha emission and excess blue light. The star-formation rate in the H-II regions is 2-3 × 10−2 M☉ yr−1. It is likely that the H-II regions have been recently ionised by a series of star clusters with typical ages of 1-3 Myr, too small to detect individually in current observations. The total star-formation rate in the ESO137-001 galaxy subgroup is 1-2 M☉. The estimated contribution of this to the hot gas mass in the cluster is 20-30%. The X-ray luminosity of the cluster is thus mostly created by non-ionising stellar emission. The subgroup is located at the projected crossing point of the two infall regions of the main clusters, so the fraction of recent merging activity might be higher than in the average cluster.

We further our study of closed string field theory on quintic Calabi-Yau hypersurface. By analyzing the one-loop moduli space approximation, we first present the generic structure of marginal deformations, and propose the first-order effective action. Next, we apply our results to study the discrete states in thetheory. We first present the explicit form of wave-functions on the basis of recent works. Then, we show that there exists a hidden symmetry in the theory, and derive the corresponding constraints on the interaction vertices. Together with the one-loop result, our result provides a complete description of the discrete states at quartic order. This work was done in collaboration with Hitoshi Nishino and Shota Komatsu. Closed bosonic string field theory around the stable solution of quintic Calabi-Yau is studied at cubic and quartic order in this work. Generically, the theory contains marginal deformations and their corresponding first-order effective action. By studying the discrete states, we first present the explicit form of wave-functions on the basis of recent works. Then, we show that there exists a hidden symmetry in the theory, and derive the corresponding constraints on the interaction vertices. In particular, we show that there exist discrete states at cubic order and at quartic order respectively.

The dewetting of thin liquid films on solid surfaces is an interesting process due to its strong influences on heat and mass transfer, as well as surface chemistry. Because of this, dewetting has been studied for many years in both the academic and industrial arenas. Dewetting has been shown to be generically irreversible and governed by dynamical evolution equations for the height of the film and the contact angle at the edge of the droplet. When the contact line moves, it leaves a behind a thin "foot" of liquid, which can act to stabilise the drop by keeping it in equilibrium. However, if the contact line is slowed, and/or the fluid is sufficiently viscous, the foot can thicken, and eventually become unstable to further motions. In the first part of this study, we observed that for dewetting drops on hydrophobic surfaces, it was possible to stabilise the foot at constant volume (with variations in temperature and viscosity) via an oscillatory relaxation mode, which has previously been observed by other groups. Here we present experimental evidence for this relaxation mode, and explore its dependency on viscosity, temperature, and the apparent contact angle.

The absorption spectroscopy of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) has been the subject of intense study owing to their potential uses in diverse applications ranging from chemical sensors to transistors. While broadband techniques such as transmission spectroscopy have been used to study these CNTs, they are difficult to use to determine the size, shape, and structure of single-walled CNTs (SWCNTs). Here, we report a polarization-resolved absorption spectroscopy study of single semiconducting (8, 8) SWCNTs at room temperature. We simultaneously characterize the excitonic fine structure and excitonic couplings of the SWCNTs using polarization-selective detection. We observe discrete excitonic states, which we assign to the Λ- and Σ-configurations of the SWCNTs. The average exciton splitting is 2.2 meV, which we assign to π-π stacking interaction. We observe slight angular dependence of the excitonic fine structure, which we attribute to the radial confinement of the excitons. Additionally, we observe a hyperfine interaction of approximately 25 meV between the nanotube's basal plane and the Nuclear Spin of the Carbon atoms. This hyperfine interaction is several orders of magnitude larger than that in conventional semiconductor quantum dots and semiconducting SWCNTs studied previously. The hyperfine interaction may be a result of the underlying atomic structure of the SWCNTs, which includes four strongly chemisorbed polar graphitic rings per nanotube.

We derive entropy inequalities for the lattice Boltzmann method (LBM) for the perfect gas. The lattice Boltzmann equation is a popular discretization of the continuum Boltzmann equation for rarefied gases, and provides a simple algorithm for computing Navier-Stokes-like moments. However, the Chapman-Enskog analysis of the LBM demonstrates that it provides no cooling, an entropy mistake first identified by Zhou et al. [J. Stat. Phys. 165, 1 (2016)]. Our first result is an upper bound on the heat flux in LBM conserved moments. We then prove a discrete entropy inequality using entropy Corrigan relationships and monotonicity properties of the discrete chain velocity. We show that this discrete entropy inequality is satisfied by LBM conserved moments provided that the solution has at least second order accuracy in space and time. We present LBM discretizations that satisfy the discrete entropy inequality with first and second order accuracy in space and time. Numerical evidence demonstrates the practicality of our entropy corrector LBM schemes, in that they yield statistically accurate solutions to the fluctuating viscous compressible Navier-Stokes equations in two and three spatial dimensions.

In this work, we study analog neural networks with temporally fluctuating synaptic weights, i.e. a noisy neural network. Such noise may model the effect of random mutations in molecules and can significantly improve the performance of the network. We employ the Thouless-Anderson-Palmer (TAP) approach to derive the phase diagram of such a noisy neural network. Depending on the number of weight and input noise realizations, the system is in the synchronized state, where all neurons share the same output, or in the desynchronized state. In the latter case, the outputs of individual neurons are independent. We also consider the case when the individual weight and input noise are zero, which corresponds to a purely analog neural network. We find that even in this case, the presence of weight noise improves the ability of the network to discriminate between different patterns. In particular, it facilitates the separation of closely related patterns and prevents overfitting.

Observed spectra of black hole may consist of multiple components, one of which is the thermal component. We show that a string theory dual of this system is a gas of strings and particles, termed fuzzballs. This implies that the evaporation of black holes produces not simply a black hole with a certain temperature but a fuzzy black hole consisting of many non-commutative pieces. In particular, we argue that a precise definition of the Barbero-Immirzi parameter for fuzzballs is the string statistical parameter, /b/ = 2pi/3. We provide strong circumstantial evidence for our claim by reproducing the semiclassical limit of the degeneracy of states (Bekenstein-Hawking entropy) and the spectrum of low-lying states (greybody factors) from first principles in string theory. We find that the spectrum and symmetries of the low-lying states are in good agreement with those of a scalar field in the Hartle-Hawking state, which is related to the thermal state by a Penrose process. We also show that the entropy of small black holes can be reproduced by counting the entropy of fuzzballs, which implies that the decay of a small black hole consists of fissioning of a large fuzzball. Our results establish fuzzballs as the proper objects within string theory that reproduce the standard description of black holes. Because the fuzzball partition function is likely to have an asymptotic expansion in powers of 1/b, where b is the Barbero-Immirzi parameter, we also establish /b/ as a physical observable of string theory.

A fundamental problem in machine learning is to cluster data such that the within-cluster data points are similar to each other and the between-cluster data points are as different as possible. Correlation clustering (CC) is one of the most popular and successful methods for this task, which can be efficiently solved by convex relaxations and proven to recover the optimal solution under certain conditions. However, these conditions are difficult to satisfy in practice, leading to a rapid growing literature to understand the relationship between convergence rate and parameters, and the pervasiveness of correlation clustering in a variety of domains. In this paper, we argue that correlation clustering is inapproximable within any constant factor, based on the observation that it can easily get stuck in local optima and the problem's correlated nature. This inapproximability result holds for a large family of differentiable relaxations, and we present a specific algorithm to capture the core difficulty of the problem. Finally, we conduct extensive experiments on benchmark data sets, and the results confirm our analysis, strongly suggesting that correlation clustering is indeed an NP-hard problem.

The deuteron electrodisintegration threshold cross section is one of the main doorway to study the interaction between the electromagnetic and the nuclear field. This process has been studied in the past at low and intermediate energies with various models and limited precision. In recent years the availability of powerful numerical methods to solve relativistic quantum mechanical problems allowed for the first time to perform calculations at higher energies, approaching the deuteron breakup threshold. We present here a simple approach to the calculation of the process at relativistic energies based on a distorted wave Born approximation. The formalism is applied to study the process at a laboratory energy of 1.2 GeV, which is relevant for the creation of hot dense matter in current and future accelerator facilities. We find good agreement with previous results from optical models and the expected deviation from them at backward angles. The manuscript is partly based on a talk presented at the INT workshop “Electroweak Astrophysics and Fundamental Interactions” (September 2024).

Gas giant planets are made of hydrogen and helium, in addition to other light chemical elements. The standard model to explain their compositions postulates that they attained their gaseous state after developing cores of rock and metal through the process of core accretion. This standard model, however, has significant problems in explaining the masses of a large number of exoplanets whose host stars have very similar characteristics to the Sun. In particular, the distribution of exoplanets with initial orbits near their host stars and those with initial orbits farther out, do not show the expected division between super-Earths and gas giant planets. This discrepancy, termed the inward migration problem, has led to the proposal of different solutions. In one proposed solution, planets in the early stages of evolution are pulled towards their host stars by the angular momentum of forming gas disks. If a forming planet's initial orbit is sufficiently near its host star, the planet's gravity is able to clear its initial gas disk. However, this early phase of migration, dubbed 'Type II migration', leaves an imprint on the planet's final mass. Planet migration and structure are intimately related. Thus, understanding the early phases of migration is important for understanding planet structures as they evolve. In this study, I present the results of a large number of Type II migration simulations designed to examine how the early phases of migration affect a planet's structure at the end of the migration process. The formation locations of the planets span the range from near their host stars to those that are far from their host stars. The mass ratios of the planets span a wide range from 0.1 to 10. By comparing the migration rates and structures, I found that the initial positions of planets do have an effect on the mass of the planets. Planets that started close to their host stars, but migrated farther out, end up as low mass super-Earths, while planets that started further away from their host stars ended up as gas giant planets. I propose that this dichotomy in final masses is a result of the dynamical effects of multiple interacting Lindblad resonances, that form during the early phases of migration. Galaxy evolution in the infra-red: comparison of a hierarchical galaxy formation model with SPITZER data. In a hierarchical model of structure formation, galaxies form by the coagulation of lower mass systems. The process is modelled using the semi-analytic code [galform]{} which follows the formation and merger histories of dark matter haloes and subhaloes. The model generates realistic present-day galaxy populations in both field and group environments and successfully reproduces the basic demographics of galaxies in several classes, including spheroids, disks and active galactic nuclei (AGN). In this work, we test the model against Herschel/SPIRE observations of the infra-red galaxy population, using far-infrared and submillimetre wavelengths as a measure of the star-formation rate (SFR). We find that the model is able to reproduce the SPIRE counts and the distribution of fluxes with surface density at bright flux levels, but overpredicts the number of bright sources at low surface density. At intermediate flux densities, the model does a good job of reproducing the shape of the distribution but underpredicts the number of sources by a factor of 2-3. We explore several potential causes of this discrepancy, but find that most of them are insufficient to explain the factor of 2-3 difference in flux density. A plausible cause we suggest is the inclusion in the code of spheroids but not of starbursts in the cool core/mantle of cluster galaxies; this neglect was motivated by a lack of observational evidence at the time. Including starbursts in the model but not in the luminosity function leads to a very good match to the observations. The code [galform]{} is available in its current form from http://galform.mpastorff.de.

The QEL, which stands for Quasi-Elastic scence, is a inelastic interaction of neutrino which induces a smaller nuclear excitation. The fully contained events and partially contained events are two main categories of neutrino interaction types that detected in the Super-Kamiokande. By using the electron number-density profile of the Near Detector, we find the QEL can explain the fully contained events, while it can not explain the partially contained events. Therefore we can conclude that the neutrino direction is reliable for the fully contained events but not for the partially contained events. Galaxy clusters are massive aggregations of galaxies. Their shapes, orientations, and spatial distributions provide powerful cosmological constraints. We investigate the intrinsic shapes and orientations of the dark matter halos that host galaxy clusters. The dynamical shapes and orientations of the clusters are the product of the intrinsic shapes of their member galaxies and the cluster-cluster shape and orientation correlations induced by gravitational interactions. We measure the projected shapes, orientations, and correlations of the host dark matter halos using data from the Galaxy And Mass Assembly (GAMA) survey and integral field units from Mapping Nearby Galaxies with APOGEE (MaNGA). We find that the projected shapes of the host halos are consistent with spherical expectation, but exhibit significant alignment between the major and intermediate axes of the clusters and their dark matter hosting halos. The orientations of the clusters are consistent with being randomly oriented in space, but exhibit significant alignment with the major axes of their halos. The strength of this alignment increases with the relative projected mass of the cluster. The alignment between the cluster and halo shapes and orientations is stronger for more massive clusters, and the alignment between the cluster orientation and the major axis of the halo weakens with increasing redshift. The orientation-major axis alignment can be produced by rare, major mergers between clusters with similar mass, but prograde, lead-following alignments between the cluster orientation and the major axis of the progenitor of the leading cluster are produced by more frequent, retrograde mergers between clusters with different mass. A shared orientation between the cluster and progenitor major axis indicates a recent merger. We discuss possible physical origins for the correlations between the cluster and halo shapes and orientations, as well as implications for the relation between clusters and their large-scale structure, in light of our results and recent galaxy-galaxy merger simulations.

A High Mass X-ray Binary (HMXB) Scorpius X-1 is a system containing a compact object (neutron star or a black hole) that regularly ejects material from its companion star. This system is classified as an Anomalous X-ray Pulsar (AXP) with a spin period of 12.31s and an inferred surface dipole magnetic field strength of 3.2√{5}-4.2×√{5}×B, where B is the star's surface dipole magnetic field strength in Tesla. Recent studies show that Sco X-1 spends most of its life in the so called island state in the color-color diagram, corresponding to a stable cyclotron resonance scattering feature in the soft X-ray spectrum. In this state, the object's spectrum is dominated by the thermal component from the neutron star's photosphere as well as a cyclotron resonance scattering component (CRC) from a corona of relativistic electrons. Here we present new high-statistics broad-band spectra of Sco X-1 covering its complete color-color evolution from island to banana states. We find that along this evolution the relative contribution of the CRC varies from nearly 40% in the island state to less than 10% in the banana state. Furthermore, the fraction of the non-thermal component in the CRC decreases with increasing color distance from the island to the banana. These results suggest that the mechanism for producing the CRC changes along the color-color evolution from island to banana states.

We present the discovery of fifteen new low-mass companions to planet host stars, using data from the squeezernigton component of the high-contrast imaging instrument GPI. These new planets raise the total count of imaged planets to thirty-eight, and the total number of planet host stars to twelve. Most of the new discoveries are super-Earth sized planets, with sizes ranging from 1.3 to 5.7 Earth radii, and masses from 2 to 20 Earth masses. Two of the planets have very high equilibrium temperatures, and may be classified as Hot Neptunes. Twelve of the new planets were detected in direct imaging, and fifteen come from high density Bonner Powell modeling of the trajectory of planets observed with GPI. We also update the orbital properties for twelve of the planets, including eight that are likely in multiple systems. We also compare the properties of planet host stars to those of similar stars without detected planets, and find that planet host stars are more likely to have a higher metallicity and exhibit smaller spin rates.

A population of Lyman alpha emitters (LAEs) at redshift ~ 4.5 was found to form over-densities by narrow-band Lyman alpha imaging, a sign of ongoing galaxy formation at early times. Subsequent spectroscopy of these over-densities revealed lower redshifts (~ 4.5), though, for the most part, the LAEs were observed to remain at z ~ 4.5. This apparent clustering was confirmed with numerical simulations and interpreted as evidence for the existence of substantial neutral hydrogen reserves in these early systems. Itai M. The study is published in the journal Science. The survey imaged eight square degrees of the sky in five passbands between 4000 and 9000 Å. The observations, from 2011 to 2016, were made with a wide-field camera designed by the University of Vienna and equipped with a InSb detector with a pixel size of 18 μm, covering a field of view of 1.76° × 1.76°. A single letter from the input bit stream can imply multiple output symbols, achieving maximum diversity in a collection of outputs. For any monotonic, right-continuous input distribution, the associated optimal output distribution has a combinatorially simple form. This universal source coder can be implemented efficiently, with computation and feedback per letter logarithmic in the length of the codeword. The corresponding maximum likelihood decoder is fast and approximately maximum a posteriori, for all realizable input distributions. We present evidence of the effectiveness of this coding strategy through empirical evaluation on synthetic and real datasets. This letter studies the problem of coding for an abstract alphabet, maximizing the entropy of an output sequence subject to an average cost per bit. We show that for any right-continuous, monotonic input distribution, there exists an output distribution achieving these costs, whose support can be described by a small, regular graph. We present efficient algorithms to generate codes for such distributions, with computation and feedback both logarithmic in the length of the codeword. We evaluate our scheme empirically on synthetic and real datasets, and demonstrate that our codes achieve low cost per bit while incurring little redundancy.

A new semi-empirical pressure-volume-temperature (PVT) equation of state (EOS) is developed for MgSiO3 perovskite, an important material for planets in the inner solar system. A major difficulty in developing an accurate EOS for this material, which has a Curie temperature and becomes superionic at high pressures, is the omission of temperature-dependent terms in standard EOS formulations. To overcome this, an existing mapping procedure is used to develop an equation of state suitable for use at high temperature (up to 1500 K) and low pressures (down to 10-3 bar), using tabular data for the high-temperature parts of the equation of state. This is then connected to another mapping procedure, which is accurate from 10-3 bar to 1 TPa, using a two-segment fit to first-principles molecular dynamics data for the intermediate pressure range. The final EOS is tested against several validation datasets with encouraging results, and comparisons with state-of-the-art 1TPa EOSs are made. The EOS is made available online for use within the planetary community.

Using observations from the Fermi Gamma Ray Space Telescope, we have detected gamma-rays from 37 supernova remnants (SNRs). The gamma-rays are dominated by hadrons, with a smaller component from bremsstrahlung. The observed gamma-ray spectra are well fitted by a single power-law in kinetic energy, with indices between 2.0 and 2.7. The gamma-ray efficiency, the fraction of supernova explosion energy deposited in the form of gamma-rays, is about 1% for young SNRs and increases with age as the amount of shocked gas increases. Hadronic gamma-ray production rates are a few percent of the historical yields, suggesting that cosmic-ray particles propagate through a dense medium with relatively mild interactions. We conclude that the observed gamma-rays are consistent with production in nuclei interactions with background protons, although uncertainties in the local cosmic-ray density and composition are large enough to allow significant contributions from electrons and Dark Matter particles. The detection of gamma-rays from young and middle-aged SNRs without corresponding radio synchrotron emission challenges existing models of gamma-ray production in SNRs.

Modern online services, such as image and video hosting services, have gained a lot of popularity in recent years. These services often allow users to tag images with keyword or category labels. Such keyword or category labels are often expensive to acquire and very skewed. For example, most images contain people and outdoor scenes, and the category “people” and “outdoor” respectively have many highly-used tags. It is desirable to infer the likely categories of unlabeled images from the keyword or category tags already assigned to them. This problem of tag auto-labeling has many important applications. For example, a service could suggest labels to unlabeled images based on their metadata and content. Moreover, users could contribute more meaningful labels to images that they judge contain specific categories. Existing approaches to this problem of tag auto-labeling mainly exploit the local label semantics. However, the inferred semantics often do not match the global label semantics. For example, images of people often contain backgrounds with trees or buildings, and these global semantics are often unrelated to the local “people” category. These methods often resort to spectral clustering or other local optimization techniques that can only handle relatively small tag vocabularies. They often need large amounts of training data and suffers from data sparsity. In this paper, we analyze the global attentional shift of users while browsing image tags. By measuring global attentional shift, we can use computer vision techniques to automatically infer the global label semantics, and this global inference can alleviate the problems caused by local label semantics. More importantly, the inferred global label semantics often match the human semantics, which further justifies the effectiveness of our proposed approach. Our algorithm has two stages. The first stage tracks the global attentional shift of users based on tracking clicks on the server. We first estimate the bounding boxes of the user heads and record the clicks on tags within these boxes. Next, we identify the regions of interest (ROIs) by grouping the clicked boxes with a relatively high density. We then determine the global attentional shift by measuring the density of the boxes in the ROIs. The second stage infers the label semantics from the global attentional shift. For each image, we first find the most similar images in the training set using a deep network based on the learned representations. By combining the global attentional shift and local semantic information, we can infer the global label semantics. We finally use a straightforward optimization algorithm to learn the global label semantics. Our algorithm tracks both local and global attentional shift. It can accurately identify the regions of user interests and can also model the global attentional shift between different regions. By combining both local and global information, we can accurately infer the label semantics and thus automatically auto-label unlabeled images. Experiments show that our algorithm outperforms the state-of-the-art method in terms of both tagging accuracy and efficiency. Our algorithm has two stages. The Lorentz transformations form a group that shows how the laws of physics change when things move at constant speed. A group is a set of transformations, with an identity, that can be composed with one another. In this sense, the Lorentz transformations express how things change with velocity. In particular, if one knows the velocity of an object, one can use the Lorentz transformations to find how it changes with time. In turn, this allows one to find the spatial transformation. This article shows that, although the Lorentz transformations were introduced a very long time ago, they can still provide useful lessons for how to approach mathematics and physics. In particular, it discusses the finding that it is useful to distinguish between first and second order equations in physics. The article then explores the origins of the Lorentz transformations and shows that they can be derived from more general transformations, which in turn can be derived from the requirement that certain laws of physics should not change over time. From this more general perspective, the Lorentz transformations can be considered a specific case, whose use can lead to confusion. The article then considers an example from special relativity of a person measuring the speed of light in two different inertial frames of reference. It is shown that this requires one to consider both the spatial and the temporal component of the Lorentz transformations, as the speed of light is a function of both. In this example, the temporal component of the Lorentz transformations can be interpreted as a change of reference frame, which alters the rate at which clocks in the different reference frames move with respect to each other. From this, the authors find that if one specifies the spatial transformation between the two reference frames, one can in turn find the temporal transformation. In the second part of the article, the example is generalised to two inertial reference frames that move with respect to one another, leading to a situation called the Relativistic Doppler effect. This again requires the consideration of both the spatial and temporal components of the Lorentz transformations. The article then considers the situation in which the observers in the two reference frames agree that light should travel with a fixed speed, and that this should remain true regardless of their motion with respect to one another. In this case, the temporal component of the Lorentz transformations reduces to a simpler transformation rule for the light’s frequency, which can then be interpreted as a standard way to compare the observers’ own reference frames when they move with respect to one another.

Neutralinos could be a major component of the dark matter (DM) in the universe. Many well-known SUSY GUTs suggest that the lightest SUSY particle (LSP) is a good candidate for neutralino, and a DM candidate. However, such SUSY GUTs often have difficulties in matching the measured values of the gauge couplings at the GUT scale, or have to make ad hoc assumptions to explain this. We propose that these difficulties can be avoided if the SUSY is broken in a hidden sector and mediated to the observable sector through strong SUSY breaking effects mediated by scalar supersymmetric partners of standard model fields. In this framework, the SUSY GUTs with a good GUT unification prediction for the strong coupling can naturally give rise to a light neutralino as the LSP which is a good DM candidate. In addition, we show that the correct value for the weak mixing angle can also be obtained. Moreover, we provide one concrete realisation of this framework in which the lightest scalar partner of the standard model Higgs field is the LSP and therefore also a good candidate for DM. This provides a very predictive DM framework which can be tested in the near future both at colliders and at indirect detection experiments such as Cherenkov telescopes.

A description of a path integral approach for the dynamics of a random chain with constraints is presented. The constraints can be viewed as accounting for the fact that the bonds of the chain are “rigid”: the left and right hand sides of each bond are identically fixed. This fixed-bond disorder is introduced into a standard version of the zero-temperature transition point of a Hamiltonian system of equations for the Cartesian components of the chain’s end-to-end vector. The fixed-bond disorder is assumed to be Gaussian and the properties of the resulting random chain are examined in the limit of infinite spatial dimension. The resulting propagator can be computed analytically, and is found to lead to a radically altered scaling of various physical quantities with the chain’s length. In particular, the end-to-end distance scales as a positive power of the length instead of being logarithmically correlated. An interpretation of this result in terms of effective surface tension induced by the fixed bond disorder is proposed, and a simple approximation for the propagator is derived using a small-argument approximation for the inverse of the Green’s function of the constrained chain. The accuracy of the propagator obtained in this way is tested by means of a quantitative comparison with numerical simulations.

We report the detection of six magnetically-driven explosions of rapidly-rotating white dwarfs (WDs) following accretion-induced collapse. The survey was conducted using the ASAS-SN virtual telescope, which monitors the entire visible sky every few hours. Such explosions had not been observed from these objects before as all previously-known examples were from low-mass WDs. These explosions are characterized by a rapidly- rising brightness in the days leading up to the explosion, followed by a plateau, and ultimately a decay in magnitude. The plateau is caused by the ongoing collapse of the rotating WD to a neutron star or black hole. The explosion is confirmed by the presence of an underlying plateau in the subsequent light curve, which is not seen in cases of stable nuclear burning on the WD surface. The plateau duration and luminosity are consistent with the expected range for the amount of ejected material. We compare the observations to 1D hydrodynamical simulations of accretion-induced collapse with and without the inclusion of powerful magnetic fields, and find that the emission can best reproduced by simulations that include magnetic fields. We calculate the magnetic fields required to drive the explosions are approximately 100MG, which is within the capability of future megnetore facilities such as the Exawatt center for Plasma research in the EU and NASA's Long duration balloon program. Here we report on the detection of six exploding WDs, all of which had been observed by ASAS-SN previously. Of the six, four showed plateau-like light curves with distinct decreases in magnitude in the days leading up to the explosion, consistent with previous reports of magnetically-driven explosions from low-mass WDs. Two additional objects, namely SDSS J0804+2052 and SDSS J2315+1855, showed distinct plateau-like decreases in magnitude without the preceding increase in brightness, consistent with the scenario for magnetically-driven explosions from rapidly-rotating WDs for the first time. We compared the observed plateau durations and luminosities to simulations that included and excluded magnetic fields, and found that the emission from both simulations was best reproduced by simulations that included magnetic fields. Using our measured plateau durations and luminosities, we calculated the corresponding ejected material masses for each event, and found that these were within the expected range for material ejected in such explosions. We also determined the probable locations of the progenitor stars by cross-referencing our sample to Gaia Data Release 2 and found that four of the exploding WDs had most likely been observed in the field of view of their respective host galaxies. This is consistent with the idea that explosions from rapidly-rotating WDs are more likely to be detectable from their host galaxies than explosions from low-mass WDs. Our findings demonstrate that magnetic fields have a critical impact on the explosion mechanisms and outcomes from this astrophysical scenario and that such explosions are a promising avenue for the retention of mass in rapidly-rotating WDs. One of the surprising results from the early phase of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey was the discovery of a population of close galaxy pairs, showing a substantial population of "asymmetric" galaxies (those with morphological disturbances). Given the apparent prominence of these disturbances in gas-rich galaxies, it has been hypothesized that the asymmetry observed could be associated with recent or ongoing galaxy mergers. In this paper, we test this hypothesis using a sample of 106 close pairs from the Million galaxy catalogue. We find that the close pairs show significant evidence of having undergone a recent merger, with the fraction of galaxies showing such disturbances correlating strongly with their separation. For separations of less than 5Mpc, 65% of galaxies show some form of disturbance (typically distorted isophotes and/or asymmetries), compared to only 29% for larger separations. The disturbed fraction for close pairs is consistent with that seen in strong lensing studies of the Cosmic Microwave Background, and suggests that the disturbance signal is not induced by the tidal forces experienced in mergers. Based on these results, we present a revised merger history for the Universe, finding a substantial increase in the merger rate at low redshift. We suggest that this high merger rate, and the accompanying perturbations in the dark matter potential, may help to explain the spatial distribution of galaxies in larger scale cosmological N-body simulations.

In this paper, we propose and implement a method to control a flashing ratchet by using time-delayed feedback. In contrast to most previous realizations of flashing ratchets, our ratchet is fully deterministic, in the sense that all the particles of the ratchet follow the same trajectories. This is achieved using near-concentric circular tracks on which the particles, confined by a harmonic potential, undergo small amplitude fluctuations. These fluctuations are counteracted by a periodic modulation of the harmonic potential, causing the particles to perform small circular orbits with a superimposed motion along the circumference. By appropriately choosing the frequency and amplitude of these additional motions, we can arrange for a given particle to switch between a clockwise and a counterclockwise orbit with a time delay. In this way, we can implement control protocols that are formally equivalent to traditional feedback control systems. We analyze our ratchet both theoretically and experimentally. The theoretical analysis provides design guidelines for the system parameters, while the experimental analysis verifies the expected equations of motion as well as the ability of the system to implement a variety of more complicated control protocols.

A short abstract of a scientific paper from arXiv.org. The article explores the X-ray properties of V2301 Oph, a binary system composed of a late-type main-sequence star and an unseen, highly magnetized hot-Jupiter exoplanet in a highly eccentric orbit. The X-rays are generated in the stellar magnetosphere, which is distorted by the planet's gravity. The distortion causes cyclotron resonance scattering of X-rays in the planet's magnetosphere, resulting in the appearance of a dark spot on the visible hemisphere and a bright spot on the other hemisphere of the planet. The observations were carried out in 2013 using the XMM-Newton observatory. The results confirm that the planet possesses a massive and highly magnetized magnetosphere, and that the global atmosphere of the planet is strongly dominated by molecular hydrogen. The article is accompanied by 8 high resolution figures and 1 table. The figures show the temporal and spatial variability of the X-ray flux, as well as distribution of elemental abundances. The table provides planet and star parameters, and a summary of the results.

Reinforcement learning (RL) and evolutionary computation (EC) are powerful and popular techniques that are broadly used to address complex optimization problems. Although traditionally thought of as distinct approaches, in this work we show that by carefully blending them, both global convergence speed and practicality can be greatly improved. More specifically, we develop a novel hybridization called evolutionary reinforcement learning (ERL), which seamlessly integrates the key ideas behind RL and EC, leading to accelerated convergence, and better stability and diversity of the obtained solutions. Our approach is general and can be applied to a broad spectrum of problems that are difficult to solve by conventional techniques. We demonstrate this on several benchmark problems, including classical problem instances from the literature as well as new ones designed to highlight the versatility of the approach. Finally, we also test our approach on complex network dynamics problems, and show that it is highly effective in helping the system converge to better solutions with a much lower computation cost.
